Subject: [sfraves] Rebirth of a Nation - DJ Spooky

THE PERFORMANCE ART EVENT OF THE SEASON:
DJ SPOOKY'S REBIRTH OF A NATION REMIXES HISTORY
A Performance Work by Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky That Subliminal Kid

Fri & Sat, Mar 25 & 26, 2005, 8 pm =E2=80=A2 Theater
  =09=20
=09$45 orchestra/$32 balcony Regular
$41 orchestra/$29 balcony Seniors
$34 orchestra/$24 balcony YBCA Members, student/teacher
  =09
  =09=20
  =09OR CALL THE BOX OFFICE TO INQUIRE ABOUT SPECIAL TICKET OFFERS:
415.978.ARTS (2787)
  =09
YBCA proudly presents Rebirth of a Nation by Paul D. Miller (DJ
Spooky), a daring multimedia performance work that explores and
explodes issues of race, politics and image manipulation. The highly
controversial 1915 silent film Birth of a Nation provides the raw
material for the performance which features the film and other images
mixed on three giant screens to a score written and performed live by
DJ Spooky.


Also don't miss out on these exciting related events=E2=80=A6

Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky That Subliminal Kid
Rhythm Science

Thu, Mar 24, 6:30 pm =E2=80=A2 Theater

FREE with a ticket to DJ Spooky's Rebirth of a Nation OR with same-day
gallery admission ($6).
FREE for students/teachers/seniors.

Don't miss this amazing opportunity as Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky
presents Rhythm Science =E2=80=93 a "live" multi-media presentation on the
history of digital art and media from the unique viewpoint of a DJ
artist. The lecture presentation will focus on how DJ culture has
evolved out of the same technologies that are used for digital media
and art.

SPECIAL SCREENING:
The Birth of a Nation
by D.W. Griffith
(1915, 175 min, 16mm)
Introduced by Alison Bing, Editor, Writer and Art Critic
  =09=20
=09Sun, Mar 20, 2 pm =E2=80=A2 Screening Room
$8 regular
$5 YBCA Members, seniors & students
  =09

In conjunction with DJ Spooky's live performance Rebirth of a Nation,
we present a screening of the landmark film on which the performance
is based. D.W. Griffith's epic saga of the Civil War expanded the
boundaries of storytelling on the screen, conveying a richer, more
complex tale than any movie before it. What continues to be
problematic about The Birth of a Nation is its still-shocking racism.
Griffith, whose political ideas were naive at best, seemed genuinely
surprised by the criticism of his masterwork, and for his next project
turned to the humanist preaching of the massive Intolerance. Boycotted
and protested from the start, Birth sold more tickets than any other
movie (a record that stood for decades), and President Woodrow Wilson
famously compared it to "history written in lightning."

--=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Rebirth of a Nation - DJ Spooky

Where is "THEATER"?  It never really says what theater, lol

YBCA? What is YBCA?

This sounds frickin' dope though. Loves it.
----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
To: "partykids" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, March 07, 2005 4:53 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Rebirth of a Nation - DJ Spooky


THE PERFORMANCE ART EVENT OF THE SEASON:
DJ SPOOKY'S REBIRTH OF A NATION REMIXES HISTORY
A Performance Work by Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky That Subliminal Kid

Fri & Sat, Mar 25 & 26, 2005, 8 pm  Theater

$45 orchestra/$32 balcony Regular
$41 orchestra/$29 balcony Seniors
$34 orchestra/$24 balcony YBCA Members, student/teacher


  OR CALL THE BOX OFFICE TO INQUIRE ABOUT SPECIAL TICKET OFFERS:
415.978.ARTS (2787)

YBCA proudly presents Rebirth of a Nation by Paul D. Miller (DJ
Spooky), a daring multimedia performance work that explores and
explodes issues of race, politics and image manipulation. The highly
controversial 1915 silent film Birth of a Nation provides the raw
material for the performance which features the film and other images
mixed on three giant screens to a score written and performed live by
DJ Spooky.


Also don't miss out on these exciting related events

Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky That Subliminal Kid
Rhythm Science

Thu, Mar 24, 6:30 pm  Theater

FREE with a ticket to DJ Spooky's Rebirth of a Nation OR with same-day
gallery admission ($6).
FREE for students/teachers/seniors.

Don't miss this amazing opportunity as Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky
presents Rhythm Science  a "live" multi-media presentation on the
history of digital art and media from the unique viewpoint of a DJ
artist. The lecture presentation will focus on how DJ culture has
evolved out of the same technologies that are used for digital media
and art.

SPECIAL SCREENING:
The Birth of a Nation
by D.W. Griffith
(1915, 175 min, 16mm)
Introduced by Alison Bing, Editor, Writer and Art Critic

Sun, Mar 20, 2 pm  Screening Room
$8 regular
$5 YBCA Members, seniors & students


In conjunction with DJ Spooky's live performance Rebirth of a Nation,
we present a screening of the landmark film on which the performance
is based. D.W. Griffith's epic saga of the Civil War expanded the
boundaries of storytelling on the screen, conveying a richer, more
complex tale than any movie before it. What continues to be
problematic about The Birth of a Nation is its still-shocking racism.
Griffith, whose political ideas were naive at best, seemed genuinely
surprised by the criticism of his masterwork, and for his next project
turned to the humanist preaching of the massive Intolerance. Boycotted
and protested from the start, Birth sold more tickets than any other
movie (a record that stood for decades), and President Woodrow Wilson
famously compared it to "history written in lightning."

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

March 4th:  ModILLfied @ Shadow Lounge
March 5th:  Clandestine in SF
March 11th:  Urbanology
March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 14th:  Turntablaze Radio on 102.5FM
April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty

> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
> > To: "partykids" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > Sent: Monday, March 07, 2005 4:53 PM
> > Subject: [sfraves] Rebirth of a Nation - DJ Spooky
> > 
> > THE PERFORMANCE ART EVENT OF THE SEASON:
> > DJ SPOOKY'S REBIRTH OF A NATION REMIXES HISTORY
> > A Performance Work by Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky
> That Subliminal Kid
> > 
> > Fri & Sat, Mar 25 & 26, 2005, 8 pm  Theater
> > 
> > $45 orchestra/$32 balcony Regular
> > $41 orchestra/$29 balcony Seniors
> > $34 orchestra/$24 balcony YBCA Members,
> student/teacher
> > 
> >   OR CALL THE BOX OFFICE TO INQUIRE ABOUT SPECIAL
> TICKET OFFERS:
> > 415.978.ARTS (2787)
> > 
> > YBCA proudly presents Rebirth of a Nation by Paul
> D. Miller (DJ
> > Spooky), a daring multimedia performance work that
> explores and
> > explodes issues of race, politics and image
> manipulation. The highly
> > controversial 1915 silent film Birth of a Nation
> provides the raw
> > material for the performance which features the
> film and other images
> > mixed on three giant screens to a score written
> and performed live by
> > DJ Spooky.
> > 
> > Also don't miss out on these exciting related
> events
> > 
> > Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky That Subliminal Kid
> > Rhythm Science
> > 
> > Thu, Mar 24, 6:30 pm  Theater
> > 
> > FREE with a ticket to DJ Spooky's Rebirth of a
> Nation OR with same-day
> > gallery admission ($6).
> > FREE for students/teachers/seniors.
> > 
> > Don't miss this amazing opportunity as Paul D.
> Miller aka DJ Spooky
> > presents Rhythm Science  a "live" multi-media
> presentation on the
> > history of digital art and media from the unique
> viewpoint of a DJ
> > artist. The lecture presentation will focus on how
> DJ culture has
> > evolved out of the same technologies that are used
> for digital media
> > and art.
> > 
> > SPECIAL SCREENING:
> > The Birth of a Nation
> > by D.W. Griffith
> > (1915, 175 min, 16mm)
> > Introduced by Alison Bing, Editor, Writer and Art
> Critic
> > 
> > Sun, Mar 20, 2 pm  Screening Room
> > $8 regular
> > $5 YBCA Members, seniors & students
> > 
> > In conjunction with DJ Spooky's live performance
> Rebirth of a Nation,
> > we present a screening of the landmark film on
> which the performance
> > is based. D.W. Griffith's epic saga of the Civil
> War expanded the
> > boundaries of storytelling on the screen,
> conveying a richer, more
> > complex tale than any movie before it. What
> continues to be
> > problematic about The Birth of a Nation is its
> still-shocking racism.
> > Griffith, whose political ideas were naive at
> best, seemed genuinely
> > surprised by the criticism of his masterwork, and
> for his next project
> > turned to the humanist preaching of the massive
> Intolerance. Boycotted
> > and protested from the start, Birth sold more
> tickets than any other
> > movie (a record that stood for decades), and
> President Woodrow Wilson
> > famously compared it to "history written in
> lightning."
> > 
> > --
> > --------------------------
> > < Brandon / DJ Bam >
> > 
> > DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
> > http://www.evilbreaks.com
> > 
> > March 4th:  ModILLfied @ Shadow Lounge
> > March 5th:  Clandestine in SF
> > March 11th:  Urbanology
> > March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary
> Party
> > April 14th:  Turntablaze Radio on 102.5FM
> > April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty

> > > From: "Bam" <invibe@gmail.com>
> > > To: "partykids" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> > > Sent: Monday, March 07, 2005 4:53 PM
> > > Subject: [sfraves] Rebirth of a Nation - DJ Spooky
> > >
> > > THE PERFORMANCE ART EVENT OF THE SEASON:
> > > DJ SPOOKY'S REBIRTH OF A NATION REMIXES HISTORY
> > > A Performance Work by Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky
> > That Subliminal Kid
> > >
> > > Fri & Sat, Mar 25 & 26, 2005, 8 pm =C3=A2=E2=82=AC=C2=A2 Theater
> > >
> > > $45 orchestra/$32 balcony Regular
> > > $41 orchestra/$29 balcony Seniors
> > > $34 orchestra/$24 balcony YBCA Members,
> > student/teacher
> > >
> > >   OR CALL THE BOX OFFICE TO INQUIRE ABOUT SPECIAL
> > TICKET OFFERS:
> > > 415.978.ARTS (2787)
> > >
> > > YBCA proudly presents Rebirth of a Nation by Paul
> > D. Miller (DJ
> > > Spooky), a daring multimedia performance work that
> > explores and
> > > explodes issues of race, politics and image
> > manipulation. The highly
> > > controversial 1915 silent film Birth of a Nation
> > provides the raw
> > > material for the performance which features the
> > film and other images
> > > mixed on three giant screens to a score written
> > and performed live by
> > > DJ Spooky.
> > >
> > > Also don't miss out on these exciting related
> > events=C3=A2=E2=82=AC=C2=A6
> > >
> > > Paul D. Miller aka DJ Spooky That Subliminal Kid
> > > Rhythm Science
> > >
> > > Thu, Mar 24, 6:30 pm =C3=A2=E2=82=AC=C2=A2 Theater
> > >
> > > FREE with a ticket to DJ Spooky's Rebirth of a
> > Nation OR with same-day
> > > gallery admission ($6).
> > > FREE for students/teachers/seniors.
> > >
> > > Don't miss this amazing opportunity as Paul D.
> > Miller aka DJ Spooky
> > > presents Rhythm Science =C3=A2=E2=82=AC" a "live" multi-media
> > presentation on the
> > > history of digital art and media from the unique
> > viewpoint of a DJ
> > > artist. The lecture presentation will focus on how
> > DJ culture has
> > > evolved out of the same technologies that are used
> > for digital media
> > > and art.
> > >
> > > SPECIAL SCREENING:
> > > The Birth of a Nation
> > > by D.W. Griffith
> > > (1915, 175 min, 16mm)
> > > Introduced by Alison Bing, Editor, Writer and Art
> > Critic
> > >
> > > Sun, Mar 20, 2 pm =C3=A2=E2=82=AC=C2=A2 Screening Room
> > > $8 regular
> > > $5 YBCA Members, seniors & students
> > >
> > > In conjunction with DJ Spooky's live performance
> > Rebirth of a Nation,
> > > we present a screening of the landmark film on
> > which the performance
> > > is based. D.W. Griffith's epic saga of the Civil
> > War expanded the
> > > boundaries of storytelling on the screen,
> > conveying a richer, more
> > > complex tale than any movie before it. What
> > continues to be
> > > problematic about The Birth of a Nation is its
> > still-shocking racism.
> > > Griffith, whose political ideas were naive at
> > best, seemed genuinely
> > > surprised by the criticism of his masterwork, and
> > for his next project
> > > turned to the humanist preaching of the massive
> > Intolerance. Boycotted
> > > and protested from the start, Birth sold more
> > tickets than any other
> > > movie (a record that stood for decades), and
> > President Woodrow Wilson
> > > famously compared it to "history written in
> > lightning."
> > >

Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) Cannabass 3/9 :: Cubehead : Doubleday : Spicious Taste

Wed 3/9

Cubehead (The Hitmen)
Doubleday (Swatchdog Recordings)
Spicious Taste (Cannabass)

Yo! We've got bass for your face, and a case full of mace. Give chase in 
the space and keep pace in the race. Don't place the lace on the vase of 
disgrace.

This wednesday is another fat dose of jungly mayhem, and don't forget 
the Cannabass drink specials:

$3 ALL DRAFTS
$3 MARGARITAS

Come get your drink on and your groove on while we're still charging no 
cover.

Oh, BTW, 4/20 is on Wednesday this year. Keep on the lookout for a 
slamming party that night!!!

--------------------------------

Every Wednesday

OPEN DECKS from 8p-10p. Get out of your bedroom and come play on a
professional sound system in an awesome booth. Bring your vinyl and/or
CDs, and your headphones and come grab a 1/2 hour slot. This is open to
ALL styles of music.

 From 10p-2a come hear weekly headliners, mostly Drum & Bass, but we mix
in some UK Grime, 2-Step, Hip Hop, Downtempo and other juicy sounds. 
Featuring the Cannabass residents: Happy, Lewt, Spicious Taste and 
Zigmund Void.

The Bench and Bar is a huge club in downtown Oakland, with a LOUD sound
system, large wooden dance floor, 3-mile long bar and a smoking patio.
It's just 2 Blocks from the 19th St BART Station.

21+ / No Cover
$3 ALL DRAFTS
$3 MARGARITAS

Bench and Bar
2111 Franklin St
Oakland, CA
510-444-2266

www.cannabass.com

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary w/ General Midi and Roxiller - Live

two things:

one, the $10 online presales for the party will only be available
until this Friday, March 11th.  after that, online presales will be
$15.  i hate to see my friends pay full price, and even though $10 is
actually way below our break-even price, i want you all to get in for
cheap!

two, in the past year, Evil Breaks has grown very close to my heart. 
it started very casually about a year and a half ago when i randomly
bumped into Aaron Jae at a club and he handed me a cd.  we started
talking online about how we loved breaks and that we wanted to see
more breaks shows.  se we somewhat prematurely decided to start
throwing parties and to start pushing breaks at underground and above
ground shows.  our first show was Furious at the dungeon in March of
2004.  since then it's been a wild ride of joy and excitement and
heartache and stress.  it's been a privelage to have seen many of you
out at our events.  and with that, i'd like to invite all of you to
our birthday bash!  it'd mean a lot to us to have you celebrate with
us.

Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary
Saturday, March 19th
9pm-4am
@ 330 Ritch, SF

Featuring:

General Midi - (TCR/Kilowatt/Distinctive) - UK
Roxiller Live - Chris Carter & JHz (TCR/Record Records/Sober) - UK

Special guest-
Corey Edwin (IAG/Sober) - Miami

Plus all the Evil Breaks residents:

Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks/AaronJae.com)
DJ Bam (Evil Breaks/Invibe.com)
M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)
Influence (Evil Breaks/nfluence.net)
Athena (Evil Breaks) Tahoe, CA
Nick Nyquil (Evil Breaks/Ill Behavior)

$10 very limited presales online only @
http://www.groovetickets.com/ordersystem/Groove/eventviewqb.asp?AffilID=93&EventsID=14956&PGname=Evil+Breaks

$15 presales @ www.Groovetickets.com, Reverb(sf), and Skills(berkeley)

$20 at the door the night of the event.

This show is guaranteed to sell out, so to make sure you've got a
place at the party, please buy your presales now.

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.evilbreaks.com

March 4th:  ModILLfied @ Shadow Lounge
March 5th:  Clandestine in SF
March 11th:  Urbanology
March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
April 14th:  Turntablaze Radio on 102.5FM
April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty

Roxiller - Live


> two things:
>
> one, the $10 online presales for the party will only be available
> until this Friday, March 11th.  after that, online presales will be
> $15.  i hate to see my friends pay full price, and even though $10 is
> actually way below our break-even price, i want you all to get in for
> cheap!
>
> two, in the past year, Evil Breaks has grown very close to my heart.
> it started very casually about a year and a half ago when i randomly
> bumped into Aaron Jae at a club and he handed me a cd.  we started
> talking online about how we loved breaks and that we wanted to see
> more breaks shows.  se we somewhat prematurely decided to start
> throwing parties and to start pushing breaks at underground and above
> ground shows.  our first show was Furious at the dungeon in March of
> 2004.  since then it's been a wild ride of joy and excitement and
> heartache and stress.  it's been a privelage to have seen many of you
> out at our events.  and with that, i'd like to invite all of you to
> our birthday bash!  it'd mean a lot to us to have you celebrate with
> us.
>
> Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary
> Saturday, March 19th
> 9pm-4am
> @ 330 Ritch, SF
>
> Featuring:
>
> General Midi - (TCR/Kilowatt/Distinctive) - UK
> Roxiller Live - Chris Carter & JHz (TCR/Record Records/Sober) - UK
>
> Special guest-
> Corey Edwin (IAG/Sober) - Miami
>
> Plus all the Evil Breaks residents:
>
> Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks/AaronJae.com)
> DJ Bam (Evil Breaks/Invibe.com)
> M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)
> Influence (Evil Breaks/nfluence.net)
> Athena (Evil Breaks) Tahoe, CA
> Nick Nyquil (Evil Breaks/Ill Behavior)
>
> $10 very limited presales online only @
>
http://www.groovetickets.com/ordersystem/Groove/eventviewqb.asp?AffilID=93&EventsID=14956&PGname=Evil+Breaks
>
> $15 presales @ www.Groovetickets.com, Reverb(sf), and Skills(berkeley)
>
> $20 at the door the night of the event.
>
> This show is guaranteed to sell out, so to make sure you've got a
> place at the party, please buy your presales now.
>
> -- 
> --------------------------
> < Brandon / DJ Bam >
>
> DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
> http://www.evilbreaks.com
>
> March 4th:  ModILLfied @ Shadow Lounge
> March 5th:  Clandestine in SF
> March 11th:  Urbanology
> March 19th:  Evil Breaks One Year Anniversary Party
> April 14th:  Turntablaze Radio on 102.5FM
> April 29th:  Thrust w/ Lee Coombs @ Mighty

 OH fuckYeah!!!
 sucks i got to miss this months party... Have a ball along with the rest of
the gang.
Koroma
Date: March 10, 2005 (2nd Thursdays)

Event Name: UpLift

Event Description:

Come join AuraSF for another evening of kick ass progressive house in a no
stress atmosphere. Plenty of parking, drink specials including $2 beers and
$3 wells and free video games are part of the AuraExperience we bring to
you.

Along with our resident DJs: Koroma  Floorcraft  J.C.  Iyad

We will have special guest DJs:

Jonas Robledo (SF-Vibe) ChrisFabbri (doublefresh, wonkavators)
and

DJ Pistachio www.djpistachio.com

on the walls...artwork from

Chris Fabbri, LeoZK, DeeDee neon lights, Toney Burkhart photos, Dominique
Cognee photos & Beryl Fine photos

Please support our local artists by visiting their websites!

There is no cover all night so make it an inexpensive night out on the town
with some bangin' beats and great people!

Venue: SubLounge

Address: 628 20th Street @ 3rd Street, San Francisco, CA

Time: 7pm - 1am

Cover: Free All Night

Subject: [sfraves] one.week.to.go...

And I'll be in London for a day and then flying out to Berlin the
next. Decided to not bother with London until later. Just not OK with
a 2 to 1 ratio on my money so they get the finger for now. I've got a
German girl living at my friend's house who's a total house head and
parties a lot back home. She's got me all setup with people in Cologne
so that's where I'll be playing a bit more. All I know is I can't wait
to on foreign soil finally...

http://www.sninesix.com/archive/nyc20005 (pictures from new.york.city)

On that nyc note. I love SF, but I think I'll be living in NYC next if
I move back to the US. SF is just too fucking slow for me these days
now that I've had a taste of NYC. I got there and it felt like home.
Big, eh, yeah sorta, but still felt small to me. SF has charm and good
people (good house scene too), but it's far too complacent and chill.

:: r ::

"What I am against is quotas. I am against hard quotas, quotas they 
basically delineate based upon whatever. However they delineate, quotas, I 
think, vulcanize society. So I don't know how that fits into what everybody 
else is saying, their relative positions, but that's my position." George W. 
Bush (our president)

Subject: [sfraves] Phuturo Tuesday Night!!  OH WOW!!!

So yeah... it was kinda an adventure even b4 i got 2 Phuturo.. like I rode
bus to bart & on bart I was asked by a lady 2 help her non speaking uncle/
Dad to get 2 the City... there was the trasfer point @ Mcarthur & well..
it was kinda hard @ 1st 2 tell the non english speaking man 2 transfer &
luckily when i said transfer he said, "Aaaaaah transfer" & I asked "Tu
Comprende?" & he said "Si"  so that was interesesting.... LoL

Then i spent the next 2 hours hopin around the City via Muni... went 2
SOMA.. Muni.. went 2 Sunset... Muni... Went got Upper Haight.. Muni... got
2 Lower Haight.. Yay!!

OK, In like Summary... Raise openedup the floor lastnight & he played
alota like well.. it was Hard boomin Jungle w/ like alot Rock kinda music
in it... I mean.. like Rock Jungle =)  Yeah!!  LoL  Then 4Real & Genome
did a fuckin' Bad Ass Tag Set!!  The set was just nice, Yummy, Dark, hard,
& Bouncy the way I Like it!!! YAY!!  OH my gosh man.. the floor was
getting packed during this set & WOW.. so Dope... So many people i ain't
seen in 4ever man.. So Dope!  OH Man.. Loved it!!!  YAY

OK.. so this was funny.. like I mean.. it got hot alot inside & I kept
goin' out 2 the front 2 chill.. so like this 1 time during the night I
totally went out 2 have a Cig & la la la.. so I"m talkin' 2 my HOmie
Artuer & kind lost like my balance kinda & took a kinda step back & turned
around... LoL... Klute was behind me & he said, "Oshby.. how u doin'
Mate?"... LoL... Hello 2day.. that was funny.. so we talked 4 a a few
minutes & Artuer like ran 2 his car 2 get some Klute vinyls 4 him 2 sign
the sleve cover thingie.. it was cute 'cause he was like all star
struck... but it was Dope.. Klute & I like talked about stuff we been
talkin' on AIM 4 like a few weeks now & stuff.. YAY!!!

OK.. needless 2 say his set was fuckin' AWESOME!!!  I LOVED it!!!  I
mean... ok.. so shoot me if I'm wrong when he was playin' some hard Dubby
tracks, alota jump up, mmmmmmmmmm, LoL.. he did rewinds on the CD
players... it was fun & I DMAO so much that night!!!

Oh yeah... needless 2 say, it was an Awesome fuckin' night!  The energy
was fuckin' sick.. Mondo People in Mondo Groovy Sprits!!  Wow!!  LoL...
had so much fun & it was good bein' back @ Phuturo after a while...  hmmmm

Afterwards me & Audio Angel went up 2 the booth & talk 2 him...  LoL... it
was Dope!!  Klute like totally brought in this Awesome energy w/ his set
that night that just , i dunno... brought something Groovy just 4 that
night & I really believe that he help rejuvenate something in the dnb
scene in the City that we needed & there's gonna be some major UK talent
comin' out these next few weeks spinning all around SF.... man... So
Dope!!  UK Invasion.. Hello 2Day.. wooohooo! =)

OK... I must i dunno... hmmm.. I'm confuzed.. i gotta do soemthing....


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: oops

hi all.  just rescribed after five+ years of disappearance from sfraves.

thanks for sharing this link.  surprised that the guy didn't check
himself into the hospital right away; or someone should have advised
him to do so.  i didn't see him pointing the gun at anybody and that
was a good thing.  shouldn't have fired empty shot into the air but i
suppose it was for demonstration.  i believe the rule to carry gun is
pointing nozzle to ground.

no, i'm no gun expert.  just a couple of trips to the shooting range. 
learned a lot and brought my friends along the next.  after
instructing friends on gun handling and safety and ready to relax.. 
guy friend almost blew up his finger because one hand was holding too
near nozzle of gun.  then lady friend stepped up and consistently hit
target that i had failed to hit.  either she was pulling my leg or
watching too many "Kill Bill" reruns :)  i definitely pay utmost
appreciation for my lady friend thereafter, for not only did i receive
hugs and pecks from her at parties, she was also my bodyguard even
though she didn't know it :)

have a great day folks.

l&hugs.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Almost packed...

I lived 4 hours south of NYC for a collective 20 years, and have been there 
many times. I think the party scene in NYC, by and large, sucks asscookies 
through a liposuction straw. People who think they're way more beautiful and 
glamorous than they are, overpriced everything and if you go down from the 
club level to the "rave" level, it's 15 year old dust-heads as far as the 
eye can see. 140bpm pace? YES. But you have to suffer through the dregs of 
society to live it.

Ugh.

I can only guess that for those who didn't grow up on the other coast that 
it holds some sort of odd charm, but I am well over it...

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Almost packed...

I'm talking pace of life. The electronic dance music scene there isn't
much and to them it's rather passe. It's really a big bar life town
full of people that love to drink, but don't like to dance so much. My
take on NYC and it's EDM scene is that it's pretty dead compared to
SF. However the pace of life there is shit fuck ton faster than SF
which thinks it's big and fast, but really it's a sleepy city by the
bay in comparison to NYC. That's why I say SF is a 122 - 128bpm city.
Oh yeah and go figure that most of the house music in SF is right in
that range too. Hahahaha.

All I know is that SF feels too slow to me. I think after living there
for a year in 1999 the allure of the city wore off and I learned just
how small it was and how it wasn't really that fast paced at all.
Maybe it was back when the party scene was blowing up and I had my
head wrapped around trance and nrg, but that was then and now that's
not the case. SF is seriously a huge a house capital for the nation
and for that it rocks. Anyone that I meet that loves house I tell to
go to SF. Finding a club with house in SF is like shooting fish in a
barrel.

:: r ::

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Want It Radio - sundays 3-7pm PST (+loop 24/7)

--0-1416096844-1110481493=:65789
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

buongiorno
 
Want It Radio continues to embitter the inhabitants of surrounding apartments by pumping out fresh house, breaks, and techno all week long! or maybe they're tuned into the loop and dancing around, and that's what all that banging is.
 
check it out for yourself:
 
http://radio.wantit.org
 
our guest this past week was DJ Trixxx, a breakbeat freak from Santa Cruz. he threw down some of the new hotness and some of the classic bangers... dope! it was a rockin' set, and lovely music to get steaming drunk to, which i did.
 
as always, appearances by the Want It residents DJ Chai, DJ Malloc, and Mo Corleone are also packaged neatly into this week's loop. 
 
have a listen, and if you're interested in stopping by as a guest DJ some week then send me an email. if you have tentative plans to attend and/or play records at burning man this year, we'd be particularly happy to hear from you.
 
grazie!
 
love,
mo


*bliss does not require ignorance*

"One night fits all!"=20

Friday, March 11, 2005

FASHION : ART : DANCE : MUSIC=20

Urbanology will feature a 3 hour fashion show on an extended cat walk =
with over 10 hip west coast designers. There will also be two rooms of =
music, an art show, a B-Boy showcases, comedian performances, and much =
more! Get ready for a night of strutting, styling, schmoozing, shopping, =
and grooving. Doors open at 8pm with shows throughout the night.=20


This event will be held on the second floor in the beautiful Crown Plaza =
Hotel @ 777 Bellew Drive in Milpitas CA.=20


http://c.myspace.com/00062/55/00/62910055_l.jpg

1230-close Roger Moorehouse

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Almost packed...

Just wait till you start hitting up some of those third world countries 
and then we'll see whats up..

My take on NYC --- I went there for a while and can't see myself moving 
there. Overpriced snobbish people that are afraid to make eye contact 
with one another. Go to a club and good luck there. The people spend a 
lot on the glitz and glamour, and indeed there are some intelligent 
people there, but the front they put up is outlanding. Only in New York 
is the gentrification as bad. You can be one block in a place 
reminiscent of Italy and the following block stolling through the slums. 
Like here, right? But the difference is that there is no cross 
pollination of people and ideas across the city.  I saw a woman pay 
$5000 on a pair of socks -- she flew in to shop. You're right, the hole 
in the wall bar scene totally rocks -- but most of the reason there 
isn't dancing is because it's illegal -- theres a law against it without 
a cabaret license. The architecture is awesome. I loved the brick and 
underground.. So is the area around NYU, the only place I would even 
consider moving to.

You'll have a renewed appreciation for SF when you see more. Perhaps you 
won't move back here, but I think you'll remember it teary eyed; I don't 
doubt the words "I miss SF" will also be uttered.

-tim

innocentchild wrote:

>I'm talking pace of life. The electronic dance music scene there isn't
>much and to them it's rather passe. It's really a big bar life town
>full of people that love to drink, but don't like to dance so much. My
>take on NYC and it's EDM scene is that it's pretty dead compared to
>SF. However the pace of life there is shit fuck ton faster than SF
>which thinks it's big and fast, but really it's a sleepy city by the
>bay in comparison to NYC. That's why I say SF is a 122 - 128bpm city.
>Oh yeah and go figure that most of the house music in SF is right in
>that range too. Hahahaha.
>
>All I know is that SF feels too slow to me. I think after living there
>for a year in 1999 the allure of the city wore off and I learned just
>how small it was and how it wasn't really that fast paced at all.
>Maybe it was back when the party scene was blowing up and I had my
>head wrapped around trance and nrg, but that was then and now that's
>not the case. SF is seriously a huge a house capital for the nation
>and for that it rocks. Anyone that I meet that loves house I tell to
>go to SF. Finding a club with house in SF is like shooting fish in a
>barrel.
>
>:: r ::
>

At 01:41 PM 3/10/2005, anti_tim wrote:

>Just wait till you start hitting up some of those third world countries 
>and then we'll see whats up..
>
>My take on NYC --- I went there for a while and can't see myself moving 
>there. Overpriced snobbish people that are afraid to make eye contact with 
>one another. Go to a club and good luck there. The people spend a lot on 
>the glitz and glamour, and indeed there are some intelligent people there, 
>but the front they put up is outlanding. Only in New York is the 
>gentrification as bad. You can be one block in a place reminiscent of 
>Italy and the following block stolling through the slums. Like here, 
>right? But the difference is that there is no cross pollination of people 
>and ideas across the city.  I saw a woman pay $5000 on a pair of socks -- 
>she flew in to shop. You're right, the hole in the wall bar scene totally 
>rocks -- but most of the reason there isn't dancing is because it's 
>illegal -- theres a law against it without a cabaret license. The 
>architecture is awesome. I loved the brick and underground.. So is the 
>area around NYU, the only place I would even consider moving to.
>
>You'll have a renewed appreciation for SF when you see more. Perhaps you 
>won't move back here, but I think you'll remember it teary eyed; I don't 
>doubt the words "I miss SF" will also be uttered.
>
>-tim
>
>innocentchild wrote:
>
>>I'm talking pace of life. The electronic dance music scene there isn't
>>much and to them it's rather passe. It's really a big bar life town
>>full of people that love to drink, but don't like to dance so much. My
>>take on NYC and it's EDM scene is that it's pretty dead compared to
>>SF. However the pace of life there is shit fuck ton faster than SF
>>which thinks it's big and fast, but really it's a sleepy city by the
>>bay in comparison to NYC. That's why I say SF is a 122 - 128bpm city.
>>Oh yeah and go figure that most of the house music in SF is right in
>>that range too. Hahahaha.
>>
>>All I know is that SF feels too slow to me. I think after living there
>>for a year in 1999 the allure of the city wore off and I learned just
>>how small it was and how it wasn't really that fast paced at all.
>>Maybe it was back when the party scene was blowing up and I had my
>>head wrapped around trance and nrg, but that was then and now that's
>>not the case. SF is seriously a huge a house capital for the nation
>>and for that it rocks. Anyone that I meet that loves house I tell to
>>go to SF. Finding a club with house in SF is like shooting fish in a
>>barrel.
>>
>>:: r ::
>>
>>
>>On Thu, 10 Mar 2005 10:23:47 -0800, Van Mundegaarde
>><electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
>>
>>
>>>I lived 4 hours south of NYC for a collective 20 years, and have been there
>>>many times. I think the party scene in NYC, by and large, sucks asscookies
>>>through a liposuction straw. People who think they're way more beautiful and
>>>glamorous than they are, overpriced everything and if you go down from the
>>>club level to the "rave" level, it's 15 year old dust-heads as far as the
>>>eye can see. 140bpm pace? YES. But you have to suffer through the dregs of
>>>society to live it.
>>>
>>>Ugh.
>>>
>>>I can only guess that for those who didn't grow up on the other coast that
>>>it holds some sort of odd charm, but I am well over it...

On Thu, 10 Mar 2005 13:41:01 -0800, anti_tim <iamgod@dementim.com> wrote:
> Just wait till you start hitting up some of those third world countries
> and then we'll see whats up..
> 
> My take on NYC --- I went there for a while and can't see myself moving
> there. Overpriced snobbish people that are afraid to make eye contact
> with one another. Go to a club and good luck there. The people spend a
> lot on the glitz and glamour, and indeed there are some intelligent
> people there, but the front they put up is outlanding. Only in New York
> is the gentrification as bad. You can be one block in a place
> reminiscent of Italy and the following block stolling through the slums.
> Like here, right? But the difference is that there is no cross
> pollination of people and ideas across the city.  I saw a woman pay
> $5000 on a pair of socks -- she flew in to shop. You're right, the hole
> in the wall bar scene totally rocks -- but most of the reason there
> isn't dancing is because it's illegal -- theres a law against it without
> a cabaret license. The architecture is awesome. I loved the brick and
> underground.. So is the area around NYU, the only place I would even
> consider moving to.
> 
> You'll have a renewed appreciation for SF when you see more. Perhaps you
> won't move back here, but I think you'll remember it teary eyed; I don't
> doubt the words "I miss SF" will also be uttered.
> 
> -tim
>

and goes till 2:00AM - I hope to see you there...

On Thu, 10 Mar 2005, anti_tim wrote:

> Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 13:41:01 -0800
> From: anti_tim <iamgod@dementim.com>
> To: innocentchild <innocentchild@gmail.com>
> Cc: Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>, newstylesound@yahoo.com,
>     antitux@gmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Almost packed...
> 
> Just wait till you start hitting up some of those third world countries and 
> then we'll see whats up..
>
> My take on NYC --- I went there for a while and can't see myself moving 
> there. Overpriced snobbish people that are afraid to make eye contact with 
> one another. Go to a club and good luck there. The people spend a lot on the 
> glitz and glamour, and indeed there are some intelligent people there, but 
> the front they put up is outlanding. Only in New York is the gentrification 
> as bad. You can be one block in a place reminiscent of Italy and the 
> following block stolling through the slums. Like here, right? But the 
> difference is that there is no cross pollination of people and ideas across 
> the city.  I saw a woman pay $5000 on a pair of socks -- she flew in to shop. 
> You're right, the hole in the wall bar scene totally rocks -- but most of the 
> reason there isn't dancing is because it's illegal -- theres a law against it 
> without a cabaret license. The architecture is awesome. I loved the brick and 
> underground.. So is the area around NYU, the only place I would even consider 
> moving to.
>
> You'll have a renewed appreciation for SF when you see more. Perhaps you 
> won't move back here, but I think you'll remember it teary eyed; I don't 
> doubt the words "I miss SF" will also be uttered.
>
> -tim
>
> innocentchild wrote:
>
>> I'm talking pace of life. The electronic dance music scene there isn't
>> much and to them it's rather passe. It's really a big bar life town
>> full of people that love to drink, but don't like to dance so much. My
>> take on NYC and it's EDM scene is that it's pretty dead compared to
>> SF. However the pace of life there is shit fuck ton faster than SF
>> which thinks it's big and fast, but really it's a sleepy city by the
>> bay in comparison to NYC. That's why I say SF is a 122 - 128bpm city.
>> Oh yeah and go figure that most of the house music in SF is right in
>> that range too. Hahahaha.
>> 
>> All I know is that SF feels too slow to me. I think after living there
>> for a year in 1999 the allure of the city wore off and I learned just
>> how small it was and how it wasn't really that fast paced at all.
>> Maybe it was back when the party scene was blowing up and I had my
>> head wrapped around trance and nrg, but that was then and now that's
>> not the case. SF is seriously a huge a house capital for the nation
>> and for that it rocks. Anyone that I meet that loves house I tell to
>> go to SF. Finding a club with house in SF is like shooting fish in a
>> barrel.
>> 
>> :: r ::
>> 
>>

>>> and
>>> glamorous than they are, overpriced everything and if you go down from the

>>> society to live it.
>>>

>>> 
>>> I can only guess that for those who didn't grow up on the other coast that

Subject: [sfraves] Come-Unity and Slot Machine (was Re: [sfraves] Almost packed...)

Oh yeah, one other really cool thing about this event is SLOT MACHINE
The next generation of musicians will be also playing LIVE at Come-Unity:

Jeno and Jonah Sharp's kin formed a punk band called SLOT MACHINE. I'm 
excited to hear what the next generation of punk sound feels like. :)

KIDS ROCK

Slot Machine - bass player Yan Ingram, drummer Jasper Sharp, lead singer 
Viv Sharp and guitarist Liam Brown) is a true San Francisco  sensation 
whose youngest member is 7 and whose oldest, at 12, is still 
eligible to order a Happy Meal.


Slot Machine:

http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/12/19/PKGLTA9RM91.DTL

"KIDS ROCK

Delfin Vigil

Sunday, December 19, 2004

Slot Machine (from left, bass player Yan Ingram, drummer ...

http://sfgate.com/c/pictures/2004/12/19/pk_lotmachine033lm.jpg

KIDS ROCK
Slot Machine (from left, bass player Yan Ingram, drummer Jasper Sharp, 
lead singer Viv Sharp and guitarist Liam Brown) is a true San Francisco 
sensation whose youngest member is 7 and whose oldest, at 12, is still 
eligible to order a Happy Meal. Chronicle photo by Liz Mangelsdorf

Like every rock star, Viv Sharp knows how to avoid questions he doesn't 
feel like answering.

With his hipsterized hair mostly hidden beneath a ear-flapped wool cap, 
the lead singer of Slot Machine slouches, pouts, swings his arms from side 
to side and pretends to be more interested in testing out the swivel on 
his chair than explaining the lyrics to one of his band's new tunes, 
"Mexican Song."

"What's it about? I don't know. Tacos. Burritos," Viv says as his three 
bandmates nod in agreement, adjusting their trucker hats, beanies and 
innocently ill-fitting clothes.

Well, what else do you guys write about?

Suddenly, every eyebrow in the band has turned into a maxed-out stupid- 
question sensor.

"Uhhh ... Pizza?!?," they say, clowning another question in unison with an 
undetectable ratio of sarcasm to seriousness.

Genius.

Meet Slot Machine -- a true San Francisco sensation whose youngest punk 
rock member is 7 and whose oldest -- at 12 -- is still eligible to order a 
Happy Meal.

But don't kid yourself about the boys in this band -- Slot Machine wasn't 
born yesterday.

Formed more than a year ago at the Creative Arts Charter School in San 
Francisco (kind of like an elementary school version of "Fame"), Slot 
Machine has been perfecting its songwriting skills with steady rehearsals, 
gigs and time in the recording studio to achieve a sound its young members 
credit to such influences as the Clash, the Sex Pistols and the Ramones.

They've already got an attitude that the Tommy Lees of the world spend 
decades trying to earn. Even their names are rock star-ready.

Seven-year-old lead singer Viv is lucky the mike stand adjusts as low as 
it does.

Yan Ingram, at 10, is about as tall as his bass is long.

Lead guitarist Liam Brown, 12, digs his new VOX amplifier.

And the drummer, Jasper Sharp, 11, insists that it's totally cool playing 
in a band with his kid brother, Viv.

"Well, he doesn't get stage fright like our last lead singer," says 
Jasper, the deepest and most down-to-business voice of the band. Getting 
past pre-gig butterflies has so far been the biggest obstacle for Slot 
Machine.

"It's one thing when we play in front of people our own age," explains 
Liam, the humble one. "But we get a little more nervous in front of 
grown-ups. We worry a little about messing up in front of them. But we get 
over it once we're onstage."

The stage keeps getting bigger for Slot Machine, which nicked its name 
from a trading card game called Yu-Gi-Oh! It just sounded cooler than 
their second choice, "Wired 9."

"Yeah, Wired 9 was kind of corny," Liam says.

The venues on Slot Machine's resume include the Great American Music Hall, 
Bottom of the Hill, Rickshaw Stop and Slim's. (At 
www.reflectiverecords.com/slotmachine/slot.html you'll find performance 
dates.)

Playing nightclubs in San Francisco must come in handy for impressing 
girls at school, right?

Suddenly everyone has to adjust his instrument. Yan hides his face in his 
conveniently long black hair.

"We're not into the whole rock-star thing," Jasper says. "Music is just 
what we do."

Their goal is to play at the Fuji Rock Festival in Japan. Jasper and Viv 
have been to Japan before, but that was when they were "a lot younger."

"Yeah. I was only like 3," says Viv, admitting to an understandably 
limited rock-star recollection of his last tour of the Far East.

After Japan, the group wants to take on Spain, or maybe Thailand.

But in the meantime, the musicians will be starting off the new year by 
cutting their first record -- a 7-inch single coming out on Reflective 
Records, a predominantly electronica-oriented label owned by local DJ 
Jonah Sharp. Sharp, who records under the name Spacetime Continuum, is 
also Viv and Jasper's manager. And their father. Liam's dad is 
internationally known DJ Jeno.

"It's amazing. They've never been interested in turntables, and they hate 
the electronic music that we're into," says papa Sharp, a native of 
Scotland. "Whenever I put any electronic music on in the car, they're 
always like, 'Ahh, get that stuff off and put on some real music like the 
Ramones or something.' "

"Yeah, Liam was about 6 years old when he started singing along to a Sex 
Pistols song," says DJ Jeno, a former Londoner. "That's when I knew 
something was going on."

Long, long ago, rock 'n' roll used to be viewed as a corrupting influence 
on American youth. But Jeno, Jonah and the other Slot Machine parents see 
the band as a healthy way to keep their kids busy and creative.

"They get their homework done, rehearse once a week and play a few gigs," 
Sharp says. "They get to play music, and we get to relive our youths 
through our kids. It's fun for all of us."

Yes indeed. The kids are all right.

E-mail Delfin Vigil at dvigil@sfchronicle.com.

Page 44..."

EOF

--

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

>>> My take on NYC --- I went there for a while and can't see myself moving
>>> there. Overpriced snobbish people that are afraid to make eye contact with
>>> one another. Go to a club and good luck there. The people spend a lot on the
>>> glitz and glamour, and indeed there are some intelligent people there, but
>>> the front they put up is outlanding. Only in New York is the gentrification
>>> as bad. You can be one block in a place reminiscent of Italy and the
>>> following block stolling through the slums. Like here, right? But the
>>> difference is that there is no cross pollination of people and ideas across
>>> the city.  I saw a woman pay $5000 on a pair of socks -- she flew in to shop.
>>> You're right, the hole in the wall bar scene totally rocks -- but most of the
>>> reason there isn't dancing is because it's illegal -- theres a law against it
>>> without a cabaret license. The architecture is awesome. I loved the brick and
>>> underground.. So is the area around NYU, the only place I would even consider
>>> moving to.
>>>
>>> You'll have a renewed appreciation for SF when you see more. Perhaps you
>>> won't move back here, but I think you'll remember it teary eyed; I don't
>>> doubt the words "I miss SF" will also be uttered.
>>>
>>> -tim

> >> My take on NYC --- I went there for a while and can't see myself moving

> >> lot on the glitz and glamour, and indeed there are some intelligent
> >> people there, but the front they put up is outlanding. Only in New York
> >> is the gentrification as bad. You can be one block in a place
> >> reminiscent of Italy and the following block stolling through the slums.

> >> pollination of people and ideas across the city.  I saw a woman pay
> >> $5000 on a pair of socks -- she flew in to shop. You're right, the hole

> >> isn't dancing is because it's illegal -- theres a law against it without

> >> underground.. So is the area around NYU, the only place I would even
> >> consider moving to.

Subject: [sfraves] All's Fair in Love and Negativland

--=====================_42234720==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

All's Fair in Love and Negativland
   By Dimitri Nasrallah
   February 25, 2005

   Bay Area media-artists Negativland are considered one of the most
subversive, curious bands to emerge from the last 20 years of the 20th
century. A collective of staunchly independent and fiercely intelligent
media pranksters, their records bridge the gap between Faust and Kid606,
between the Residents and 2 Many DJ's. Since their inception in 1980,
they've thrown an entire history of counterculture, from literary satire to
folk to punk to musique concrete, into a creative blender and come up with
a mishmash of ego-debunking tape loops and bristling social attacks. As
culture-jammers, they pulled off some of the most audacious media hoaxes in
music history. As advocates for Fair Use and amendments in copyright law,
they've been embroiled in some of the nastiest legal battles. Now
celebrating their 25th anniversary, after an extended absence from the
public spotlight, they return this year with a fistful of CDs, DVDs, and
books. If any one group has deserved the notoriety of being considered
"dangerous" by the mainstream, Negativland is it. We dust off the hoaxes,
the infamous lawsuits, and the label wrangling that made Negativland the
cult legends they are today.

MORE:  http://www.exclaim.ca/index.asp?layid=22&csid1=3488






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Death is our eternal companion.  It is always to our left, at an arm's 
length.  It has always been watching you.  It always will until the day it 
taps you.  The thing to do when you're impatient is...to turn to your left 
and ask advice from death.  An immense amount of pettiness is dropped if 
your death makes a gesture to you, or if you catch a glimpse of it, or if 
you just catch the feeling that your companion is there watching you."
-Carlos Castaneda

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] BLUETECH at 1015 folsom

Hey music heads--
       I know mine isn't the first post about what could be a downright spiritual Moontribe event
at 1015 Folsom this Friday night. But if there are any fellow Bluetech fans out there, I wanted to
alert you that he'll be playing NEW stuff off his upcoming third album in his live set. If you're
interested, below I've pasted an article I wrote on him this month for the San Francisco Observer,
a small city paper often labeled with neighborhood names: the Castro Star, Western Edition (cute)
and the Haight Beat. Below that, there's a link to the full story on the Observer website if you'd
like to read the interview Q&A. Bluetech has a refreshing take on the world--check out what he has
to say. 
       If you're a Bluetech fan, feel free to hit me up--i'm relatively new out here and it would
be nice to get a sense of who's into psydub and whatnot...
       See you there!
                   jB

March SAN FRANCISCO OBSERVER
Bluetech Brings Soothing Psy Sounds to 1015 Folsom
By Jeremy Bates, Mar 08, 2005 

Like a giant oak with silicon leaves, Evan Bartholomews music grows from deep within the earth
and blossoms into our brilliant modern world. Its organic roots sip silver rainwater and sprout
bionic branches, which you can hear tapping the tangy synths and tweaking the knobs that sculpt
the psychedelic soundscapes Bartholomew inhabits under his preferred moniker: Bluetech.

Psy/chill, ambient dub, downtempo: However a shopkeeper might categorize Bluetechs sound if
required to do so for inventory, there is no mistaking the composer when you hear it. Alert,
deep-throated baselines roll in waves beneath jazzy keyboard splashes deftly fingered by the
classically trained pianist. Syncopated riffs lend a breakbeat feel to sparkling melody lines of
brushed-metallic yet joyfully warm timbre. Bright peaks sometimes surge on off beats, but even
songs lacking such classic reggae accents sway and pulse with dub undercurrents. Via crisp,
precision production, Bluetech embroiders tactile synesthesia into his aural quilts, handcrafting
seemingly three-dimensional sonic sculptures that tickle the brain and swell the spirit. Peaceful,
healing sounds surfing beats that lure listeners to the dance floor. Ear candy with soul.

Bluetech is a psy-scene favorite not only here in the Bay Area  where he grew up and got his
psy-feet wet  but all up and down the West Coast, as well. In fact, he likes to consider himself
a West Coast citizen as he can often be found in British Columbia  where he is based currently
 San Diego, and many points in between. He plays at Burning Man when he gets the chance, but is
often overseas performing live or DJ sets at other thriving events, such as Portugals Boom
Festival, Germanys Voov Festival and Underwater Overground in Croatia.

After playing at Synergenesis in November (an art, music and culture expo produced by
ExploreSpirit at CELLSpace on Bryant Street), Bluetech returns to San Francisco on March 11 for
Sound of Mind: the So-Cal desert-party troupe Moontribes takeover of 1015 Folsom. Hell be
featuring new tracks from his upcoming album  which will be his third following Prima Materia
(Waveform records) and Elementary Particles (Bluetechs own Native State Records). Both albums
were recently re-released internationally as a double CD by Israeli label Aleph Zero.

Bluetech is also eager to swoop through the Bay again in June for the Ambient Alchemy tour
(www.ambientalchemy.com). Happy to be spending some of his spring and summer at home in San
Francisco, Bluetech shares with The Observer his path from North Bayer to at-large North American,
as well as insights into his creative process.

CLICK LINK BELOW FOR FULL STORY & INTERVIEW Q&A:
http://news.sfobserver.com/news/view_article.html?article_id=171f6dcc01ed6a95a607b39713b27c45


www.batesmotel.org/jeremy

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] BSP - John Howard kicks off "Fabulous!"  March 18th (SF)


Friday March 18th: FABULOUS! Opening Night

           Third Fridays see a fresh new offering in March- Bobby Brown
and the SF-Vibe crew are back on the scene with their latest
party FABULOUS!set to debut at Levende Lounge on Friday March
18th.

Opening nightwelcomes San Francisco house legend John Howard (Om Records,
I-Mix) all the way from NYC, alongside SF-Vibe resident jocks Chad
Mitchell (Roam Recordings), Tal M. Klein (Aniligital), and everyone's
favorite Uncle, Larry (Housewax). Special guest appearance by Audio Angel
(SisterSF, Roam) funkin' it up on live vocals.

CD giveaways and strong cocktails all night long. Expect a fun night with
a diverse music format encompassing old skool hip hop to house and
everything in between. Tal M. Klein warms things up for the supper crowd
with his seductive blend of loungey beats.

Dinner reservations available at www.opentable.com.

Levende is open for after hours. Valet parking available.

Discounted $5 guestlist with RSVP to bobby@sf-vibe.com

 We're offering a limited number of VIP passes for this party. Sign up @
http://www.sf-vibe.com/fabulous/
for an opportunity to win. You'll be notified by Friday, March 18.

see you on the dancefloor!

From sfraves-return-119963-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Mar 11 17:24:21 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-119963-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 20764 invoked by uid 1103); 11 Mar 2005 17:24:20 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 20739 invoked from network); 11 Mar 2005 17:24:19 -0000
Message-ID: <20050311172417.12607.qmail@web81209.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 11 Mar 2005 09:24:17 -0800 (PST)
From: Heidi <cosmicdancer@sbcglobal.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Miss Kitten at Mezzanine 4.30.05___ FREE

I cannot believe this is going to be a free show! Just
found it in my inbox and thought I'd share it with you
guys. Hope to see you there!

love, Heidi
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Saturday April 30th
blasthaus present
Miss Kittin
at Mezzanine
10pm until 2am
21+ / $FREE

http://www.illstatic.com/venue_list.php?venue=Mezzanine#the%20415%20SESSIONS


"DJ is my main activity, working every weekend in
clubs or festivals since 1994. I started with hard
techno-acid sounds: Drop Bass Network, Analog,
Interr-Ferrence, Force Inc, SP23, to Detroit and
experimental techno. I figured out it expressed my
late teenage aggressivity. With experience, I got
musically softer and more open-minded.

Actually I play everything that entertains me:
minimal, deep, to kicking techno, mixed with funny our
leftfield tunes, classics, electro, no matter what it
is. That's why I hardly can describe my style. A 2h
monotone set really bores me. If I don't have fun
myself, I'm not able to please people.
DJing must be, in a way, something selfish. I shout it
loud: I don't do it for the people. I never pretended
to educate the audience, I just share a big part of
me, taking it as serious as I love it. Michael Mayer
(Kompakt records, Cologne) said: "Taking it serious
about having fun." Because 1st it's a job, and we
should never forget being paid to give pleasure to
people is a great privilege. If the risks I take in my
sets are my trademark, my priority is still to make
dance the ones who make my living. Question of
respect.

I think I have a sharp technique, pitch-control born
in my acid times, I consider my best weapon to focus
on musical choices.

I love playing records, it's probably the best thing I
know to do in life. I do it because it's big fun and
it makes me free, it even turns into a meditation kind
of thing. With records, nothing is planned, every
record is important. I often compares a DJ set to a
tennis game where each ball counts. But people know me
more for my voice even if I never took singing
lessons."



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

"What I am against is quotas. I am against hard quotas, quotas they 
basically delineate based upon whatever. However they delineate, quotas, I 
think, vulcanize society. So I don't know how that fits into what everybody 
else is saying, their relative positions, but that's my position." George W. 
Bush (our president)

>From: Jeremy Bates <jeremy@batesmotel.org>
>Reply-To: jeremy@batesmotel.org
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, spazlist@spaz.org, commercialfree@5lowershop.org
>Subject: [sfraves] BLUETECH at 1015 folsom
>Date: Thu, 10 Mar 2005 23:04:36 -0800 (PST)
>
>Hey music heads--
>        I know mine isn't the first post about what could be a downright 
>spiritual Moontribe event
>at 1015 Folsom this Friday night. But if there are any fellow Bluetech fans 
>out there, I wanted to
>alert you that he'll be playing NEW stuff off his upcoming third album in 
>his live set. If you're
>interested, below I've pasted an article I wrote on him this month for the 
>San Francisco Observer,
>a small city paper often labeled with neighborhood names: the Castro Star, 
>Western Edition (cute)
>and the Haight Beat. Below that, there's a link to the full story on the 
>Observer website if you'd
>like to read the interview Q&A. Bluetech has a refreshing take on the 
>world--check out what he has
>to say.
>        If you're a Bluetech fan, feel free to hit me up--i'm relatively 
>new out here and it would
>be nice to get a sense of who's into psydub and whatnot...
>        See you there!
>                    jB
>
>March SAN FRANCISCO OBSERVER
>Bluetech Brings Soothing Psy Sounds to 1015 Folsom
>By Jeremy Bates, Mar 08, 2005
>
>Like a giant oak with silicon leaves, Evan Bartholomews music grows from 
>deep within the earth
>and blossoms into our brilliant modern world. Its organic roots sip silver 
>rainwater and sprout
>bionic branches, which you can hear tapping the tangy synths and tweaking 
>the knobs that sculpt
>the psychedelic soundscapes Bartholomew inhabits under his preferred 
>moniker: Bluetech.
>
>Psy/chill, ambient dub, downtempo: However a shopkeeper might categorize 
>Bluetechs sound if
>required to do so for inventory, there is no mistaking the composer when 
>you hear it. Alert,
>deep-throated baselines roll in waves beneath jazzy keyboard splashes 
>deftly fingered by the
>classically trained pianist. Syncopated riffs lend a breakbeat feel to 
>sparkling melody lines of
>brushed-metallic yet joyfully warm timbre. Bright peaks sometimes surge on 
>off beats, but even
>songs lacking such classic reggae accents sway and pulse with dub 
>undercurrents. Via crisp,
>precision production, Bluetech embroiders tactile synesthesia into his 
>aural quilts, handcrafting
>seemingly three-dimensional sonic sculptures that tickle the brain and 
>swell the spirit. Peaceful,
>healing sounds surfing beats that lure listeners to the dance floor. Ear 
>candy with soul.
>
>Bluetech is a psy-scene favorite not only here in the Bay Area  where he 
>grew up and got his
>psy-feet wet  but all up and down the West Coast, as well. In fact, he 
>likes to consider himself
>a West Coast citizen as he can often be found in British Columbia  where 
>he is based currently
> San Diego, and many points in between. He plays at Burning Man when he 
>gets the chance, but is
>often overseas performing live or DJ sets at other thriving events, such as 
>Portugals Boom
>Festival, Germanys Voov Festival and Underwater Overground in Croatia.
>
>After playing at Synergenesis in November (an art, music and culture expo 
>produced by
>ExploreSpirit at CELLSpace on Bryant Street), Bluetech returns to San 
>Francisco on March 11 for
>Sound of Mind: the So-Cal desert-party troupe Moontribes takeover of 1015 
>Folsom. Hell be
>featuring new tracks from his upcoming album  which will be his third 
>following Prima Materia
>(Waveform records) and Elementary Particles (Bluetechs own Native State 
>Records). Both albums
>were recently re-released internationally as a double CD by Israeli label 
>Aleph Zero.
>
>Bluetech is also eager to swoop through the Bay again in June for the 
>Ambient Alchemy tour
>(www.ambientalchemy.com). Happy to be spending some of his spring and 
>summer at home in San
>Francisco, Bluetech shares with The Observer his path from North Bayer to 
>at-large North American,
>as well as insights into his creative process.
>
>CLICK LINK BELOW FOR FULL STORY & INTERVIEW Q&A:
>http://news.sfobserver.com/news/view_article.html?article_id=171f6dcc01ed6a95a607b39713b27c45
>
>
>www.batesmotel.org/jeremy
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> > > Just wait till you start hitting up some of those third world countries and
> > > then we'll see whats up..
> > >
> > > My take on NYC --- I went there for a while and can't see myself moving
> > > there. Overpriced snobbish people that are afraid to make eye contact with
> > > one another. Go to a club and good luck there. The people spend a lot on the
> > > glitz and glamour, and indeed there are some intelligent people there, but
> > > the front they put up is outlanding. Only in New York is the gentrification
> > > as bad. You can be one block in a place reminiscent of Italy and the
> > > following block stolling through the slums. Like here, right? But the
> > > difference is that there is no cross pollination of people and ideas across
> > > the city. I saw a woman pay $5000 on a pair of socks -- she flew in to shop.
> > > You're right, the hole in the wall bar scene totally rocks -- but most of the
> > > reason there isn't dancing is because it's illegal -- theres a law against it
> > > without a cabaret license. The architecture is awesome. I loved the brick and
> > > underground.. So is the area around NYU, the only place I would even consider
> > > moving to.
> > >
> > > You'll have a renewed appreciation for SF when you see more. Perhaps you
> > > won't move back here, but I think you'll remember it teary eyed; I don't
> > > doubt the words "I miss SF" will also be uttered.
> > >
> > > -tim
> > >

> > >> I'm talking pace of life. The electronic dance music scene there isn't

> > >> full of people that love to drink, but don't like to dance so much. My
> > >> take on NYC and it's EDM scene is that it's pretty dead compared to
> > >> SF. However the pace of life there is shit fuck ton faster than SF
> > >> which thinks it's big and fast, but really it's a sleepy city by the
> > >> bay in comparison to NYC. That's why I say SF is a 122 - 128bpm city.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] u.s. online record stores?

www.dropshop.com (pretty solid stock, even on the import side of things)

www.dmswax.com  (a little limited in scope, but you can get decent current 
favorites, etc.)

www.modernusic.com  (some people I know in Baltimore run this shop - they 
tend to have a solid little selection)

www.satelliterecords.com (although their service is kinda beat these days)

www.planetXusa.com (and these guys are just assholes - but they have 
selection)

Those oughtta cover you for the time being. I know good shops in the UK & 
Canada as well that aren't terribly priced. And a coule of eBay sellers that 
are tight too if you do the eBay thing.

carlos aka dj pistachio

Subject: Re: [sfraves] one.week.to.go...

i love new york but i love boston even better.

and about new york, get this.  i have a friend who lives in jersey but 
he lives only 5 minutes from the empire state building.  once you cross 
the holland tunnel you are in jersey.  it's crazy out here.  everything 
is toll roads.

and portland?  portland oregon?  no.  portland maine?  yeah.  portland 
maine is off limits right now cause they're snowed in again.  but i did 
get a peek ...

new york manhattan's look and feel is just like san francisco to me.  
boston is chill.  i think boston is going to be the next hot-spot, the 
next place to be, once they get done with this big dig stuff.  have any 
of you seen it or driven through it?  it's intense!  imagine all these 
freeways and freeway exits right underneath the city.  it would be like 
if they had extended interstate 280 and us 101 right into the middle of 
the city and put them underground and gave them interchanges and full 
entrance and exit services to boot.  absolutely amazing.  and you have 
full cell phone and fm radio in the tunnels.

i'm diggin this traveling stuff.  i'd like to live in boston for a 
while sometime.  i'll probably retire in santa cruz though, that's 
where deepfog, the name, and the infamous spirit was born.

anyway ryan have fun being away from us "paltry americans".

oh, speaking of americans, you guys should have been there when we were 
ganging up on the deer hunters we work with.  making maaaad fun of them 
and their damn magazines and spit cans they leave laying everywhere.  
that was a story for another day.  have fun.  git 'er done!

see you all at come-unity sunday afternoon ...  i've got a flight out 
of philly.

fog out

Subject: [sfraves] Moontribe Lastnight.. Oh yeah!

OK... so it was totally mondo SIK lastnight @ 1015... Hello 2day.. had
soooooo much fun!!!  OK.. striat up... Sticky spun the most Awesome Set
from lastnight that I  ever witnessed Live!!  Seriously, he started out
Ghetto Tek... in2 New Order like next, went Run DMc, then back 2 some new
wave, then oh my gosh man... he even went fuckin' New Jack City 4 a while,
alota 80's house cover sample tunes.. I LOVED IT SOOOOOOOO MUXH!!  I was
DMAO so hard...  Sticky.. I so totally Mondo thank U 4 taken us on that
Journey Dude!!!

Another Set from lastnight I LOVED so YUMMY MUCH was John Kelley!!  
Ooooooooh shit.. he went all around the world w/ his & back... I mean.. he
played some Techno.. Loved it... Techno finally in the main room as long
as I've went 2 that club, played a lil' psy trance in his set, Oh my
gosh.. BREAKBEATS!!  Loved it!!  I loved it when he dropped Acid Breaks &
oooh.. I was gone!!  Loved it!

I mean.. the music all around lastnight was So Dope!!  I mean.. I Grooved
2 alota Techno in the main room.. Oh my gosh... Techno in the Main room! 
Hello 2day!!  There was like this Breakbeats live PA upstairs @ 1 point...
OH my gosh.. so Dope! Ummm... yeah man... evertying lastnight was just
Amazing!!  The Vibe was Groovy.. I met some dude name Lon (pr Lawn) who
was wearin' a TREEHUGGER shirt which i found Ironic... OH man... saw some
old school faces i ain't seen in a while, Family totally dominated the
club which gave 1015 a homey feel... it was Sick!!  Loved it!

LoL.. I dunno man... it was just Groovby lastnight & I just had soooooo
much fun!!!  Hangin' w/ Family was an added element that seriously made a
huge diff playing around in that club!  YAY!!  LoL  Love U guys!

LOLOLOLOLOLOLOLMAO... Hello 2day.. I can't stop laughing @ what a Groovy
time it was!  LoL

Umm.. I hope y'all have a Groovy weekend & I hope i see some of y'all
grabbin' floor somewhere!  I dunno where I'll be 12night honestly 'cause
there's a few things goin' on that I hmmm.. ya konw.. I'm so confuzed!

YAY!

Thanks alot, Friends. Thanks for your support. Thanks alot for being

know me. I really appreciate how you've been there with me through
everything, and how you've shown me how people stick together, and how

alot for havin my back when I needed you. Thanks alot for tactfully
knowing when your words would have the most affect. Really, I mean it.

existed.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Moontribe Lastnight.. Oh yeah!

ahh.. 1015 - a place that i'll never forget and if you know me, i
forget very often :)
something is always to be had there if i might say modestly.  haven't
been to 1015 in ages so don't know how it's been but it's always been
around.  not sure of any management changes going on throught the
years but i must thank those who run the place for keeping it
available for all those who seek fun.  from accummulated experience, i
recall (caution: i don't remember bad things much): it has friendly
bouncers, cool djs, cool bartenders, attracting cool people to come
and dance and party, the best music and laser gears in the business
while juggling politics and laws that go into running an elaborate
place like that.  this is not easy to do folks for just making
everyone happy is not an easy thing.  i say this as a happy happy
paying customer.  in all, i've seen clubs come and go like baby
diapers but 1015 manages to be around surving through many seasons of
mainstream, underground, and sub cultures. congrats 1015!  please say
you'll always be around so that i can pass a piece of myself to my
kids when they grow up.

don't know of names and faces of folks in Family but i have heard of
them as sweet as honey.  if the Family name is the same, then there
might be a few old old timers that i might be able to recognize.  hey
osby, if you know and appreciate Family, i bet you are one cool
person.  thanks for sharing your experience.

l&hugs.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Moontribe Lastnight.. Oh yeah!

oh man, moontribe @ 1015 were awesome! i miss hearing those guys so
much! drove up from the peninsula at 2am and danced pretty much nonstop
till the end... last time i danced that much i think was at the last
moontribe :) (which was, alas, too long ago). and the crowd was so great
too! such a great vibe from everyone there.

all the dj's were really good that i heard, but especially the crazy
breaks/trip-hop/whatever you wanna call it that was happening in the
front room around 2:45 or 3am, and mr. annand's house set upstairs at
the end of the night. that guy was just on fire! i went up for the
beginning of his set all exhausted already and he just nailed the energy
of the crowd.. it started off slow, let people get into it, then built
up and drew you in. he knew exactly when to back off a bit and when to
push it up a notch. before i knew it, i, and everyone else in the room,
were completely jacking to the music :)

does anyone know who the dj was in the front around 3am? i looked at the
lineup but completely forgot. best i can describe his music, it was like
aphex twin, but way more intense :) anyways, i'm so happy that this
coincided with my visit back. friday night totally made my month!
tomorrow i'm back to relatively ravefree nyc...

gary

the Cannabass drink specials:

$3 ALL DRAFTS
$3 MARGARITAS

Come get your drink on and your groove on while we're still charging no
cover.

Oh, BTW, 4/20 is on Wednesday this year. Keep on the lookout for a
slamming party that night!!!

--------------------------------

Every Wednesday

OPEN DECKS from 8p-10p. Get out of your bedroom and come play on a
professional sound system in an awesome booth. Bring your vinyl and/or
CDs, and your headphones and come grab a 1/2 hour slot. This is open to
ALL styles of music.

 From 10p-2a come hear weekly headliners, mostly Drum & Bass, but we mix
in some UK Grime, 2-Step, Hip Hop, Downtempo and other juicy sounds.
Featuring the Cannabass residents: Happy, Lewt, Spicious Taste and
Zigmund Void.

The Bench and Bar is a huge club in downtown Oakland, with a LOUD sound
system, large wooden dance floor, 3-mile long bar and a smoking patio.
It's just 2 Blocks from the 19th St BART Station.

21+ / No Cover
$3 ALL DRAFTS
$3 MARGARITAS

Bench and Bar
2111 Franklin St
Oakland, CA
510-444-2266

www.cannabass.com


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>From: giuki+sfraves@realify.com

>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Moontribe Lastnight.. Oh yeah!
>Date: Sun, 13 Mar 2005 12:35:04 -0800

>oh man, moontribe @ 1015 were awesome! i miss hearing those guys so
>much! drove up from the peninsula at 2am and danced pretty much nonstop
>till the end... last time i danced that much i think was at the last
>moontribe :) (which was, alas, too long ago). and the crowd was so great
>too! such a great vibe from everyone there.
>
>all the dj's were really good that i heard, but especially the crazy
>breaks/trip-hop/whatever you wanna call it that was happening in the
>front room around 2:45 or 3am, and mr. annand's house set upstairs at
>the end of the night. that guy was just on fire! i went up for the
>beginning of his set all exhausted already and he just nailed the energy
>of the crowd.. it started off slow, let people get into it, then built
>up and drew you in. he knew exactly when to back off a bit and when to
>push it up a notch. before i knew it, i, and everyone else in the room,
>were completely jacking to the music :)
>
>does anyone know who the dj was in the front around 3am? i looked at the
>lineup but completely forgot. best i can describe his music, it was like
>aphex twin, but way more intense :) anyways, i'm so happy that this
>coincided with my visit back. friday night totally made my month!
>tomorrow i'm back to relatively ravefree nyc...
>
>gary

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Moontribe Lastnight.. Oh yeah!

ahh.. 1015 - a place that i'll never forget and if you know me, i
forget very often :)
something is always to be had there if i might say modestly.  haven't
been to 1015 in ages so don't know how it's been but it's always been
around.  not sure of any management changes going on throught the
years but i must thank those who run the place for keeping it
available for all those who seek fun.  from accummulated experience, i
recall (caution: i don't remember bad things much): it has friendly
bouncers, cool djs, cool bartenders, attracting cool people to come
and dance and party, the best music and laser gears in the business
while juggling politics and laws that go into running an elaborate
place like that.  this is not easy to do folks for just making
everyone happy is not an easy thing.  i say this as a happy happy
paying customer.  in all, i've seen clubs come and go like baby
diapers but 1015 manages to be around surving through many seasons of
mainstream, underground, and sub cultures. congrats 1015!  please say
you'll always be around so that i can pass a piece of myself to my
kids when they grow up.

don't know of names and faces of folks in Family but i have heard of
them as sweet as honey.  if the Family name is the same, then there
might be a few old old timers that i might be able to recognize.  hey
osby, if you know and appreciate Family, i bet you are one cool
person.  thanks for sharing your experience.

l&hugs.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Moontribe Lastnight.. Oh yeah!

i've been going to 1015 since the early days of Come-Unity, and i've=20
watched it go from wonderful, vibey, and friendly, to a police state. =20=

i was reluctant to go to 1015 last friday because of this, but the pull=20=

of Moontribe was too hard to resist. we had several MT dj's who played=20=

at the Friends & Family/Brass Tax campout last summer, and i just had=20
to see them again.

the club didn't disappoint this time. security was friendly - no=20
emptying wallets, checking pockets, tossing lip balm, etc. - just a=20
quick pat-down and we were in quickly. my friend had to leave early and=20=

get her things out of my car, and the bouncer at the door even let me=20
leave and come back in (!).

(i'm not sure if the new attitude of security was because of the crowd=20=

that was there, but it was a refreshing change from the usual treatment=20=

at 1015.)

on top of this, the front room has been remodeled, with two new=20
restrooms added, and great lighting effects on the walls. the sound is=20=

much better in the main room, and the lights are still as wild as ever.

the drinks still suck and are overpriced though.

the music was great, with John Kelly being the highlight of the evening=20=

for me, even though he didn't go on until 3:30 am. i can only imagine=20
what one of his morning sets must be like in the middle of the=20
Mojave... :-)

the afterparty... it started at around 7 am at a house in the Castro=20
that all the Moontribe people were crashing at for the weekend (all 20=20=

of them!).  the music at the afterparty was mainly MT dj's, playing=20
some 120-125 bpm stuff that was perfect for the cracked-out foggy=20
morning. i left the afterparty at 1:30 pm, and it was still going=20
strong.  amazing.

there is a MT desert party in 2 weeks, if anyone's interested.  i made=20=

some great connections at the Friends & Family campout and this past=20
weekend, and i'd love to get down to the desert to see what Moontribe=20
is like in their native environment.

carpool, anyone?  i have a passenger van that seats 8.  :-)

-philip-

> weekend, and i'd love to get down to the desert to see what Moontribe
> is like in their native environment.
