>well as one right outside the door in the hallway. Nice new beige
>berber carpeting. We do not have a house phone as we both have
>cellphones but there is a line in your room if you would like to
>activate it.
>
>
>Available April 1st - $750 month
>First and Last month + 500 Security Deposit = $2000 total move in cost
>
>This includes ALL UTILITIES: water, electricity, gas, sewer, garbage,
>cable tv, laundry, high speed internet - except telephone. (cable
>internet potentially coming soon)
>
>You: any age, sex, orientation, nationality welcome. Must be a DRAMA
>FREE, clean, stable, professional person with a good stable job
>wanting to move in by November 1st. We all pitch in on household
>shopping such as toiletpaper, lightbulbs, laundry detergent, etc and
>generally buy most of our own food but dont mind sharing everything as
>long as its kept equal as far as purchases vs consumption.
>
>There are currently two people living in the condo one in each of the
>other bedrooms. We're both males in our mid 20's. We're both sane and
>responsible, and easy to get along with. We have busy work and social
>lives that keep us out and about most of the time but we do enjoy
>spending some time hanging out at home. We occasionally have small
>dinner gatherings here or friends over to watch a movie. One of us
>works full time for a home audio/video install company, the other is a
>bay area event/marketing director. We're looking for anyone that can
>pay the rent on time, can help out in keeping the place clean from
>time to time and just basically someone that we can get along with
>enough to like living where we do. This is a one in a million location
>that everyone loves. Once you see the island and the ultimate central
>location, beauty, and amenities you will fall in love and never want
>to move anywhere else!
>
>Please reply with a little about yourself such as your job, your
>average day/week routine, any furniture you have. Need proof of
>employment and roomate references
>
>Any Q's please feel free to email for the A's.
>
>SFRoomForRent@Gmail.com
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

On Tue, 22 Mar 2005 10:46:50 +0100, innocentchild
<innocentchild@gmail.com> wrote:
> Actually I just got out of Berlin and now I'm 2.5 hours north of there
> in a lovely city called Hildesheim. Berlin was a blast. I even managed
> to find an underground party that was held in an unmarked room under
> the underground's tracks. We're talking old skool rave style where
> you're walking down some shit hole alley and you see graffitti
> everywhere including all over a door. Doesn't look like where you
> should be, but yet - you open that door and suddenly you're greeted to
> a tiny 2 room space with people smashed in there. It was all live
> electroclash PA. Let's just say the live electroclash group in SF that
> thinks they're edgey and cool - well, they'd be sent home crying after
> what I saw. Pure raw energy and talent on stage that night. They even
> had intermission acts with reenactments of that show Tutti Frutti
> here. Then they started throwing fruit and later during a song
> dedicated to a maxi-pad brand called smirk they started tossing
> maxipads into the crowd. Tit's hanging out, electrical tape and bad
> makeup with a one guy having hair like flock of seagulls really made
> the night just pure fun. I need to find their *everyone is a dj*
> track. You would all love it. No really LOVE IT. The crowd was
> awesome, the beer was cheap (=E2=82=AC2) and it was only =E2=82=AC5 to ge=
t in. Felt
> like home to me.
>=20
> We didn't leave until 7:30am or something. People stayed until the end
> too which seems to be rare these days at most parties. I didn't do
> much site seeing, but I walked around berlin for hours and hours just
> trying to get lost and find spots that I wouldn't if I had been
> hitting up landmarks. If any of you ever decide to go make sure you
> stay at The Circus hostel. So nice. So cheap. =E2=82=AC18/night and locke=
rs
> are free. You're across from the underground station at
> Rosenthaler-Platz which makes getting around a breeze.  I can't get
> enough D=C3=B6ner here. Turkish kabaab stuff.  I ate way too many of them=
.
> There's a lot more to what I did but I'm lacking the energy to keep
> typing more. Basically - went to Sage (club) and Space from Ibiza was
> hosting. Trance. Ick. Not a bad club, but definitely a summer venue
> because of the outdoor pool and open roof capability. Didn't hit up
> Tresor. It closes in 2 weeks. Oh well...
>=20
> I'll have pictures up and video too soon. For now I'm going back to
> bed and getting myself better. Stupid being sick shit pisses me off.
> Too much partying I guess...
>

Subject: [sfraves] SFRaves Planners Dinner

  In order to kick off the event planning SFRaves is hosting a dinner 
(location TBD) to celebrate our presence on this planet as a Free Resource 
to the community, as well to appreciate the SFRaves community presence in 
our lives. This dinner is to be a catalyst in planning the SFRaves 13 Year 
Annniversary Party! Please join us and realize our dreams, an event to 
celebrate our history and contribution to the local scene.

We will be meeting to discuss:

*Venue
*Sound and lighting
*DJ Lineup
*Decorations
*Permitting
*Security
*Flyers, Promotions
*Shifts
*Badges
*Structure
*Themes
*Further Agenda TBD based on SFRaves Planners input

The SFRaves-planners / SFRaves 13 Year Anniversary Dinner is tentatively 
set for date/time to be determined by SFRaves Planners feedback and input. 
This will most likely occur in the coming 2-3 weeks, so please give your 
feedback now and we'll get the reservations cracking. The Location is to 
be determined per the feedback of the list.

Ideas: For possible meeting times and dates:

Dates: Sunday April 3, 2005 @ 8pm, Monday April 4th @ 8pm
Location: Restaurant of our choice, or someone's place who is willing to 
host.

Cost: Can be free if we do a potluck, depends on who can come, where we 
meet and what the timeframe is. (Hopefully it will be low-cost due to 
everyone's limited budget)

Location: TBD

* To subscribe to SFRaves Planners list, send an email message to:

sfraves-planners-subscribe@hyperreal.org

Thank you for being part of the SFRaves Family - Peace, Love, Unity, 
Respect!

Please join SFRaves-Planners

* To subscribe to SFRaves Planners list, send an email message to:

sfraves-planners-subscribe@hyperreal.org

Please join the SFRaves Calendar Mailing List

* To subscribe to SFRaves Planners list, send an email message to:

sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

Please join the SFRaves Discussion List

* To subscribe to SFRaves Planners list, send an email message to:

sfraves-subscribe@hyperreal.org

fantasy land comprised of weak minded acronyms folks...

>Date: Wed, 23 Mar 2005 05:44:51 -0800 (PST)
>
>  In order to kick off the event planning SFRaves is hosting a dinner 
>(location TBD) to celebrate our presence on this planet as a Free Resource 
>to the community, as well to appreciate the SFRaves community presence in 
>our lives. This dinner is to be a catalyst in planning the SFRaves 13 Year 
>Annniversary Party! Please join us and realize our dreams, an event to 
>celebrate our history and contribution to the local scene.
>
>We will be meeting to discuss:
>
>*Venue
>*Sound and lighting
>*DJ Lineup
>*Decorations
>*Permitting
>*Security
>*Flyers, Promotions
>*Shifts
>*Badges
>*Structure
>*Themes
>*Further Agenda TBD based on SFRaves Planners input
>
>The SFRaves-planners / SFRaves 13 Year Anniversary Dinner is tentatively 
>set for date/time to be determined by SFRaves Planners feedback and input. 
>This will most likely occur in the coming 2-3 weeks, so please give your 
>feedback now and we'll get the reservations cracking. The Location is to be 
>determined per the feedback of the list.
>
>Ideas: For possible meeting times and dates:
>
>Dates: Sunday April 3, 2005 @ 8pm, Monday April 4th @ 8pm
>Location: Restaurant of our choice, or someone's place who is willing to 
>host.
>
>Cost: Can be free if we do a potluck, depends on who can come, where we 
>meet and what the timeframe is. (Hopefully it will be low-cost due to 
>everyone's limited budget)
>
>Location: TBD
>

>

>PacificSound <sunset@pacificsound.net> wrote: Date: Fri, 18 Mar 2005 
>13:33:54 -0800 Subject: <<<TRANSIT tonite...SUNSET postponed!!>>>
>
>* PacificSound * 415.820.1664
>
>As many of you know, the last Sunset Party of 2004 was rained out. Well, it 
>looks as though we are still lurking under this dark and wet cloud for 
>Sunday. Instead of waiting till the last minute to see if the weather will 
>clear for us we have decided to make an earlier decision and postpone this 
>Sundays Sunset Party until April 10th. This is being done for several 
>reasons.
>
>1st from the Rangers: it seems pretty promising that even if it doesn't 
>actually rain on Sunday the ground will be saturated and wet which will 
>cause the grass to be certainly torn up badly with our large group, not to 
>mention uncomfortable to sit on. This ground saturation also effects the 
>extended parking lots of Stafford Lake, these will turn to mud and cause 
>stuck cars.
>
>2nd from us: By making this decision now we will save hundreds of dollars 
>in costs for the day by being able to cancel portable toilets, the truck, 
>and generator rental with plenty of notice. We lost this money last year 
>with our late cancelation and cannot afford to do this again since we just 
>do not have the financial resources to throw away money like that. As we 
>have said before this event costs nearly $1500 to put on. Now, there is the 
>slight chance we could pull off the event between storms, but that is just 
>not where we are at after a decade of Sunset Parties. Especially for the 
>1st Sunset party off the year where we want everyone to come and enjoy 
>spring together in the sun. And especially in a year where we are doing 
>less events and want each one to be as special as it can be.
>
>So please pass the word that we will be back in action in a few weeks. 
>April 10th is first available date that will work with the Park and our 
>schedules, so hopefully this will also give you all a chance to get work 
>off again, change flights, and rental cars. So, in this fashion we will be 
>bringing in Spring with a storm of our own...back to back weekends of fun 
>since the 1st Boat party of the year will happen on April 17th on a Brand 
>New Boat for us with greater capacity and a gem of the San Francisco Bay...
>
>Thank you all for understanding and we'll see you tonite at Transit ; ) 
><<<~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~>>> 
>it is time to put your senses into motion with... What:   TRANSIT When:   
>Friday, March 18th, 2005 Where: Milk, 1840 Haight St. at Stanyan Time:    
>10pm - 2am Age:     21+ w/id Admittance:  $7 before 11pm, $10 after Sunset 
>discount: $5 before midnite with printout of this email Artists: Lance 
>DeSardi ~ you know the Landshark Galen ~ GBoy back at ya Monty Luke ~ never 
>a forgotten Stolen Moment
>
>Tasty Treats: What would Transit be without some great eats... we are 
>excited to have guest chef: Maya Scales
>
>Food as art and art that you eat. As always, come early to try a bite or 
>four because when the clock strikes midnight the chef will be on the dance 
>floor!!
>

ahh.... Costa Rica!

i'm planning a road trip to Costa Rica for next year.  you heard right, 
ROAD TRIP. it's a little insane, but how often do you get to do 
something like that?  we're going to have a veggie oil powered 1987 MCI 
motor coach for the trip.

it will take about a month to drive there.  our final destination is 
Punta Mona, a permaculture community on the caribbean coast.  
www.puntamona.org.  i'd like to hang out there for a few weeks before 
we start heading back north.

i'd like to get an idea of what else is worth seeing in C.R. so we can 
plan our trip accordingly.

anyone wanna come with us?  :-)

pxd

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Teen's love of 'Slow Ride' inspires quest

--=====================_2198280==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Teen's love of 'Slow Ride' inspires quest

Song replaced bell used to signal lunch

By Chris Moran

UNION-TRIBUNE STAFF WRITERMarch 19, 2005 CHULA VISTA - A song can champion a
cause, but in the case of a clever and persistent high school senior, the
song is  the cause.

Daniel Dorman's tale begins with a ring and ends with an overpowering
anthem. He used Gandhi-inspired tactics to confirm the power of one person
to change the world - or at least high school lunch period. And, as Daniel
explains, "Every story sounds better with the name 'Foghat' in it." The ring
is, by Daniel's reckoning, an "E-sharp" bell that dismisses fifth period and
calls Bonita Vista High School students to lunch. It annoys Daniel, and once
he decided it needed to be replaced, there was only one worthy substitute:
"Slow Ride," the classic rock staple by 70s rockers Foghat. So Daniel went
to Principal Ramon Leyba and asked: How about playing "Slow Ride" in place
of the lunch bell? Leyba was amused, and told Daniel that he'd look into it.
Really, though, Leyba thought that was the end of it. But Daniel was just
getting started.

"Gandhi beat the British Empire by not eating," Daniel said, so getting his
school to broadcast "Slow Ride" was surely attainable. Also, the 17-year-old
said, "I have a lot of free time." He put it to use with a three-page letter
that eloquently made the case for "Slow Ride." He launched a petition drive
for Proposition Slow Ride and gathered 300 signatures. He secured the band's
endorsement. Foghat sent him what drummer Roger Earl calls "Fogstuff" - CDs,
autographed photos and the like - and wished him well. Daniel didn't get any
follow-up from Leyba after the meeting, so he and his friends devised
messages in their Web design class to be delivered to Leyba daily. The first
featured a photo of Daniel and an ultimatum that the principal had 10 days
to play Foghat. If Leyba didn't play "Slow Ride," Daniel would go on a
hunger strike. It was followed the next day with a photo of Daniel holding
up nine fingers. When the countdown reached six days, Leyba called him in.
Leyba agreed to play it, but just once. He said it wasn't possible to wire
the song into the school's bell system, and he would not waste staff time
playing "Slow Ride" each day. It was a high point for a boy who had almost
dropped out of school before he got to high school. Daniel and his mom say
the trouble started when he made a threat against a teacher in a moment of
frustration. It wasn't a serious threat, but in the wake of the Santana High
School shootings that year, administrators didn't take any chances. Daniel
was transferred to Fifth Avenue Academy, a Chula Vista school that
specializes in tough cases. He thrived there for two years and then entered
Bonita Vista High in 11th grade. Daniel previously distinguished himself at
Bonita Vista High by having an apprentice - a student who followed him
everywhere, addressed him as "The Daniel," performed menial tasks for him
and dressed like him. That meant wearing a derby hat and carrying a pocket
watch. Daniel had 10 applicants for a second apprentice. They submitted
risumis providing references, listing favorite television shows and
answering questions such as, "If Daniel were to decide to miss school to
watch 'Montel,' would the apprentice write down a short synopsis of what
Daniel missed that day at school?" Yesterday at 12:36 p.m., the music
played, and Daniel's story had a triumphant ending. And it has an epilogue.
Foghat's Earl called Daniel last weekend. The drummer thought back to his
high school days and wondered what would have happened back if he had asked
his principal to play Jerry Lee Lewis' "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On." "He
probably would have kicked me out," Earl said, but this Leyba "seems like a
reasonable fellow." So when the band plays at Sycuan Casino this summer,
Daniel and three of his buddies will be there as guests of the band. Earl
said Leyba's invited, too.

Steve McLean

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Trocadero Transfer Part III

--=====================_2693493==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Feel hungry for a musical trip the likes of which were only savored at the 
Trocadero Transfer on a Saturday night?

Crave an experience that will recharge your soul with all the energy and 
spirit of the finest west coast dance club of the 70's and 80's?

Chapter three of the 'Remember' the Party series is "Soul Recharge" and 
will be featuring San Francisco's own DJ Jerry Bonham. Jerry will be 
serving up a helping of delicious, original, authentic underground music " 
la Troc", from the height of the disco era.

In the mix that Jerry brings you, will be an appetizer of a smooth flavored 
uplifting wind up. You'll sink your teeth into the entre, rich and spicy 
in it's intensity. Then stay for dessert, and enjoy the creamy sweetness of 
an early morning wind down.

As a complement to this musical feast, drink in the ambience of color and 
mood created by Bob Bear, "Arc Lamp Diva" Miss Carla and Bobby Moske, it's 
light and sparkling!

You can enjoy this delectable indulgence at its very point of origin, the 
Glas Kat, formerly known as the Trocadero Transfer, 520 Fourth Street San 
Francisco.

Make your reservations for Sunday April 24th 2005, from 6:00pm until 2:30am.

Limited advanced tickets can be purchased for $15 online at 
http://www.remembertheparty.com, or at Medium Rare Music, 2310 Market 
Street, San Francisco, or $20 at the door.

Check out our new look at: http://www.remembertheparty.com and while you're 
there read our "Brief History of the Scene" and some of the new notes on 
the on line guest book. Even if you have already signed in, feel free to 
leave us another note after all it's a party! It's the Troc.! Let's celebrate!

Cheers,

The "Maitre D' and Chefs" at White Light Productions.

Subject: [sfraves] (bsp) (nrr) Anarchist Bookfair this Saturday, super-cheap books from Subversive Soundz

Hey, so we're selling super cheap ($1!  $2!  $3!  and
up)  books at the Subversive Soundz table at the
Anarchist Bookfair this Saturday.  We're cleaning out
our collection, and have a wide variety of stuff,
including books on dance music culture, feminism,
anarchism, drugs, counterculture, health, history,
etc. as well as some great fiction, too.   Stop by and
say hello.  

here's more info. on the Bookfair this year:

Bound Together Books presents the 
10th Annual Bay Area Anarchist Bookfair
Saturday, March 26, 2005
10am to 6pm
S.F. County Fair Building
Golden Gate Park near Ninth Avenue and Lincoln Way

The largest Book Fair of its kind in North America
returns for its 10th anniversary, with over 60
vendors, caf and an impressive roster of speakers.
Admission is free. 

The San Francisco workers collective Arizmendi Bakery
will be selling food and beverages at the Caf. 

Speakers include: 

Barry Pateman - archivist at the Kate Sharpley
Library, and senior editor at the Emma Goldman Papers.
The most recent volume of Emma Goldman - A Documentary
History Of The American Years Volume 2: Making Speech
Free, 1902-1909 has just been published by University
of California Press,and he has authored introductions
to both the new edition of Alexander Berkman's 'What
Is Anarchism' and The Voltairine De Cleyre Reader 

Ward Churchill - reknowned scholar activist and
troublemaker is the author and editor of numerous
books and audio CDs. His latest work is On The Justice
Of Roosting Chickens 

Eric Drooker - legendary graphic artist whose work has
graced a thousand walls, posters, t shirts and book
covers. His seminal novel without words, Flood! is now
available again in a new elegant edition 

Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz - pioneering feminist, and
perennial activist is the author of two (to date)
autobiographies - Red Dirt: Growing Up Okie, and her
memoir of the 60s, Outlaw Woman 

Chris Carlsson spent 13 years stealing office supplies
to produce Processed World, a zine that chronicled the
drudgery of 9-to-5 desk jobs. He helped bring Critical
Mass into being, and created SHAPING SAN FRANCISCO:
The Interactive Multimedia Excavation of the Lost
History of San Francisco 

Lynn Breedlove, chief singer and songwriter for
infamous dyke-punk band Tribe 8, has been performing
throughout the U.S., Canada, and Europe for over a
decade. She currently teaches at the Harvey Milk
Institute in San Francisco,where she lives. Her first
novel, Godspeed, is not your average drug redemption
story, but its obviously based on her own experiences
as an addict in past years, and thats what makes it
so compelling and real. 

Entartete Knst (German for 'degenerate art') is an
anarcho-electro/hip-hoppers put out political
electronic music that fuses low- and high-brow culture
(think dark, slow hip-hop with Noam Chomsky samples)
into a potent mix that challenges the status quo. 

For more information, call Bound Together Books at
(415) 431-8355 

(Subversive Soundz is a project rooted in electronic
dance music and radical politics.  We try to merge the
two as much as possible, bringing politics and dance
cultures together in an unholy alliance to spread joy,
liberation, solidarity, and subversion.  We've done
actions such as helping organize and bringing sound
systems to Reclaim the Streets actions; brought
literature and propaganda to club/dance music events;
organized Unchained Reaction!, an elektronik,
anti-nuclear resist.dance party/convergence at the
gates of the Nevada Test Site as part of a larger
peace encampment; organized the outside dance area at
the annual Anarchist Cafe; and organized numerous
benefits to support efforts such as Legal Action to
Stop the War, Bay Area Indymedia, the DIY Skillshare,
and the Autonomous Mutant Festival.   Our parties are
DIY, all ages, sliding scale, diverse musically,
combine art, magick, and politix, and are done out of
love, and to build bridges between ideas and people. 

For more info, email subversivesoundz@yahoo.com. )

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR - Anyone been to Costa Rica?

Possessing a side-arm doesn't necessarily mean one will have the will
to use it in a bad situation, and if you feel you might fall into that
category, it might be to your further detriment to carry a piece,
since it can be turned against you

My girl's brother just went down to C.R. and loved it.

Also, it seems that it's one the Ex-Pat destination's of choice these
days, which makes sense, given the pounding the US Dollar is taking in
Western Europe.

Just stepping off the plane in Europa means that your precious dollar,
between the exchange rate & transaction fees loses 40% of its 'value'
right off the top.

That's some haircut.

I'm looking at C.R. as well as Belize as a place to go if shit gets
much heavier than it already is.

I'm thinking Belize because it's kind of undeveloped at this point and
the natives all speak English, and if the shit really does hit the fan
I don't believe anywhere in the 1st Werld, to include Europe, Canada
and the USA USA USA will be any place a person with any sense of
self-preservation will want to be.

nwa

Subject: [sfraves] New Attack on Raves and Live Music

--=====================_18139252==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


New Attack on Raves and Live Music

Defend Your Right to Dance!

Dear Henry,

Last year our supporters helped raise attention to an outrageous abuse of 
power in Racine, Wisconsin, where hundreds of music fans were ticketed for 
being in a crowded nightclub where a few people used drugs. Those ticketed 
had no drugs on them. The police didn't even have any evidence that they 
had ever used drugs. Their only "crime" was dancing at a nightclub where 
other people who used drugs were arrested.  Although only three drug 
arrests were made, police issued citations to 445 innocent attendees with a 
penalty of $968 each for being "patrons of a disorderly house." Thanks to a 
public outcry from people like you, work by the Drug Policy Alliance, and 
an ACLU lawsuit, the citations were ultimately dismissed.

Now, it has happened again; this time in Flint, Michigan. On Saturday the 
local police raided a popular nightclub, Club What's Next, and ticketed 
music fans who were attending a dance night known as "Getting Lucky" (the 
DJs included Halluci-Nate, Sparkimus Prime, White Rabbit, Captain Cheddar 
and California's Dj Primo.) While some people were arrested for possessing 
or selling illegal drugs, most people were ticketed for "frequenting a drug 
establishment," a misdemeanor offense.

<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=84691>Speak out against 
this abuse of power now.

That's right. In Flint, Michigan (and many other cities) if you go out 
dancing on a Saturday night and the police happen to arrest other people at 
the club for drugs, you could be charged with a drug crime even though you 
had nothing to do with drugs. These innocent party-goers now face up to 90 
days in jail and a $500 fine. They also face a criminal record with all the 
legal and social barriers that brings. Several people at the club that 
night told us club-goers were also subjected to strip searches, including 
full cavity searches  even though they had nothing to do with drugs. 
Imagine the police walking into your favorite bar or nightclub and making 
you submit to a strip search for no reason! Imagine spending 90 days in 
jail or paying a $500 fine for dancing!

The raid on Club What's Next was conducted by Flint's Special Operations 
and Crime Area Target Team units, along with the Flint Area Narcotics Group 
and the Genesee County Sheriff's Posse. We're looking into whether or not 
federal Byrne grant money helped finance the raids. (On a side note, any 
law enforcement agency that has the word "posse" in it should be suspect).

You can send a message that this type of action is unacceptable by doing 
two things:

1)      <http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=84691>Contact 
the Flint City Council and Mayor and let them know how appalled you are 
that the city mistreats music fans and allows the police to punish people 
for the crimes of others.

2)      Forward this alert to your e-mail lists and to friends and family. 
We need to flood the Flint political establishment with faxes and emails.

The Drug Policy Alliance would like to give a special thanks to Will 
Patterson at the Electronic Music Defense Fund (EM:DEF) for alerting us to 
this scandal. He found out about the incident because one of the club-goers 
filed an incident report on EM:DEF's web site. If your rights are ever 
violated by the police at a music event, you can 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=84684>file a similar 
report there. Copies of incident reports go to EM:DEF, the ACLU, and the 
Drug Policy Alliance.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

> > Actually I just got out of Berlin and now I'm 2.5 hours north of there
> > in a lovely city called Hildesheim. Berlin was a blast. I even managed
> > to find an underground party that was held in an unmarked room under
> > the underground's tracks. We're talking old skool rave style where
> > you're walking down some shit hole alley and you see graffitti
> > everywhere including all over a door. Doesn't look like where you
> > should be, but yet - you open that door and suddenly you're greeted to
> > a tiny 2 room space with people smashed in there. It was all live
> > electroclash PA. Let's just say the live electroclash group in SF that
> > thinks they're edgey and cool - well, they'd be sent home crying after
> > what I saw. Pure raw energy and talent on stage that night. They even
> > had intermission acts with reenactments of that show Tutti Frutti
> > here. Then they started throwing fruit and later during a song
> > dedicated to a maxi-pad brand called smirk they started tossing
> > maxipads into the crowd. Tit's hanging out, electrical tape and bad
> > makeup with a one guy having hair like flock of seagulls really made
> > the night just pure fun. I need to find their *everyone is a dj*
> > track. You would all love it. No really LOVE IT. The crowd was
> > awesome, the beer was cheap (=E2=82=AC2) and it was only =E2=82=AC5 to =
get in. Felt
> > like home to me.
> >
> > We didn't leave until 7:30am or something. People stayed until the end
> > too which seems to be rare these days at most parties. I didn't do
> > much site seeing, but I walked around berlin for hours and hours just
> > trying to get lost and find spots that I wouldn't if I had been
> > hitting up landmarks. If any of you ever decide to go make sure you
> > stay at The Circus hostel. So nice. So cheap. =E2=82=AC18/night and loc=
kers
> > are free. You're across from the underground station at
> > Rosenthaler-Platz which makes getting around a breeze.  I can't get
> > enough D=C3=B6ner here. Turkish kabaab stuff.  I ate way too many of th=
em.
> > There's a lot more to what I did but I'm lacking the energy to keep
> > typing more. Basically - went to Sage (club) and Space from Ibiza was
> > hosting. Trance. Ick. Not a bad club, but definitely a summer venue
> > because of the outdoor pool and open roof capability. Didn't hit up
> > Tresor. It closes in 2 weeks. Oh well...

Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:In order to kick off the event planning SFRaves is hosting a dinner 
(location TBD) to celebrate our presence on this planet as a Free Resource 
to the community, as well to appreciate the SFRaves community presence in 
our lives. This dinner is to be a catalyst in planning the SFRaves 13 Year 
Annniversary Party! Please join us and realize our dreams, an event to 
celebrate our history and contribution to the local scene.

We will be meeting to discuss:

*Venue
*Sound and lighting
*DJ Lineup
*Decorations
*Permitting
*Security
*Flyers, Promotions
*Shifts
*Badges
*Structure
*Themes
*Further Agenda TBD based on SFRaves Planners input

The SFRaves-planners / SFRaves 13 Year Anniversary Dinner is tentatively 
set for date/time to be determined by SFRaves Planners feedback and input. 
This will most likely occur in the coming 2-3 weeks, so please give your 
feedback now and we'll get the reservations cracking. The Location is to 
be determined per the feedback of the list.

Ideas: For possible meeting times and dates:

Dates: Sunday April 3, 2005 @ 8pm, Monday April 4th @ 8pm
Location: Restaurant of our choice, or someone's place who is willing to 
host.

Cost: Can be free if we do a potluck, depends on who can come, where we 
meet and what the timeframe is. (Hopefully it will be low-cost due to 
everyone's limited budget)

Location: TBD

Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:

New Attack on Raves and Live Music

Defend Your Right to Dance!

Dear Henry,

Last year our supporters helped raise attention to an outrageous abuse of 
power in Racine, Wisconsin, where hundreds of music fans were ticketed for 
being in a crowded nightclub where a few people used drugs. Those ticketed 
had no drugs on them. The police didn't even have any evidence that they 
had ever used drugs. Their only "crime" was dancing at a nightclub where 
other people who used drugs were arrested. Although only three drug 
arrests were made, police issued citations to 445 innocent attendees with a 
penalty of $968 each for being "patrons of a disorderly house." Thanks to a 
public outcry from people like you, work by the Drug Policy Alliance, and 
an ACLU lawsuit, the citations were ultimately dismissed.

Now, it has happened again; this time in Flint, Michigan. On Saturday the 
local police raided a popular nightclub, Club What's Next, and ticketed 
music fans who were attending a dance night known as "Getting Lucky" (the 
DJs included Halluci-Nate, Sparkimus Prime, White Rabbit, Captain Cheddar 
and California's Dj Primo.) While some people were arrested for possessing 
or selling illegal drugs, most people were ticketed for "frequenting a drug 
establishment," a misdemeanor offense.

Speak out against 
this abuse of power now.

That's right. In Flint, Michigan (and many other cities) if you go out 
dancing on a Saturday night and the police happen to arrest other people at 
the club for drugs, you could be charged with a drug crime even though you 
had nothing to do with drugs. These innocent party-goers now face up to 90 
days in jail and a $500 fine. They also face a criminal record with all the 
legal and social barriers that brings. Several people at the club that 
night told us club-goers were also subjected to strip searches, including 
full cavity searches  even though they had nothing to do with drugs. 
Imagine the police walking into your favorite bar or nightclub and making 
you submit to a strip search for no reason! Imagine spending 90 days in 
jail or paying a $500 fine for dancing!

The raid on Club What's Next was conducted by Flint's Special Operations 
and Crime Area Target Team units, along with the Flint Area Narcotics Group 
and the Genesee County Sheriff's Posse. We're looking into whether or not 
federal Byrne grant money helped finance the raids. (On a side note, any 
law enforcement agency that has the word "posse" in it should be suspect).

You can send a message that this type of action is unacceptable by doing 
two things:

1) Contact 
the Flint City Council and Mayor and let them know how appalled you are 
that the city mistreats music fans and allows the police to punish people 
for the crimes of others.

2) Forward this alert to your e-mail lists and to friends and family. 
We need to flood the Flint political establishment with faxes and emails.

The Drug Policy Alliance would like to give a special thanks to Will 
Patterson at the Electronic Music Defense Fund (EM:DEF) for alerting us to 
this scandal. He found out about the incident because one of the club-goers 
filed an incident report on EM:DEF's web site. If your rights are ever 
violated by the police at a music event, you can 
file a similar 
report there. Copies of incident reports go to EM:DEF, the ACLU, and the 
Drug Policy Alliance.




Moksha Tribe: www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101: http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is: "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive. Jump into experience 
while you are alive! What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death. If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] i finally did it! yes!

last night i took another step up the DJing ladder and successfully
executed a technique that is rare in the world of nightlife:

i pushed "stop" on the wrong turntable.  dead silence for a good 1.5
seconds as i stood like a deer in headlights befaddled as to what just
happened.

yes, this is the first time i've ever done this.  ever.  i've never
done it at home.  i've never done it playing out.  finally! 
success!!!

next goal:  pick up the wrong needle.

oh, it will happen.  it will!!!!

--

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

------ Forwarded Message
> From: jennifer blum <jen@5lowershop.org>
> Date: Thu, 24 Mar 2005 10:34:11 -0800
> To: "spazlist@spaz.org" <spazlist@spaz.org>
> Subject: [SpAzLiSt] Wendy's diner finds human finger in her chili
> 
> http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/03/24/MNGPUBU27R1.DTL
> 
> 
> Wendy's diner finds human finger in her chili
> 
> Maria Alicia Gaura, Dave Murphy, Chronicle Staff Writers
> Thursday, March 24, 2005
> 
> An unlucky diner bit into a segment of a human finger while digging into a
> bowl of chili at a Wendy's restaurant in San Jose, Santa Clara County health
> officials confirmed Wednesday.
> 
> The diner, who visited the restaurant Tuesday night, spit out the well-
> cooked digit, notified restaurant workers and became sick to her stomach,
> health officials said.
> 
> The origin of the finger remains a mystery.
> 
> Santa Clara County Health Officer Dr. Martin Fenstersheib said he was called
> at home by San Jose police who went to Wendy's and immediately dispatched
> health inspectors to the restaurant. He said he ordered officers to
> transport the body part, wrapped in damp gauze, to the medical examiner's
> office. 
> 
> The restaurant, at 1405 Monterey Road, was shut for a couple of hours while
> the batch of chili and stocks of chili ingredients were impounded. The
> restaurant was allowed to reopen and to cook another batch of chili using
> newly purchased ingredients.
> 
> Wendy's officials said they are eager to find out how their food became
> contaminated. 
> 
> "The entire investigation is with the county health department,'' said Steve
> Jay, Wendy's marketing director for Santa Clara County. "We're fully
> cooperating.'' 
> 
> Jay said the chili came from a master distributor but declined to name the
> firm. He added that Wendy's has been doing business in the area for more
> than 25 years and never had a serious problem before.
> 
> Fenstersheib said he spoke to the anxious woman several times by phone and
> had the queasy experience of confirming to her that the object was
> indisputably human. The woman asked officials not to name or even describe
> her. 
> 
> "I had to confirm it to her that she had indeed put a piece of a human
> finger in her mouth," Fenstersheib said. "She kind of lost it."
> 
> The woman was "emotionally distraught ... due to the unpleasant sensation of
> having this (object) in her mouth," Fenstersheib said
> 
> He said the finger had been cooked at a high enough temperature to kill any
> viruses, including hepatitis or HIV, and that it was very unlikely that she
> will suffer any health effects from her experience, aside from psychological
> trauma. 
> 
> "The potential for health impacts are extremely low for her or anyone else
> who ate that chili," Fenstersheib said. He said, however, that he will
> recommend baseline viral testing for the woman, to allow for comparison
> should any food-borne illness emerge in the coming months.
> 
> A similar strategy might be wise for others who ate the contaminated food,
> he said. "The risk is low, but nothing in medicine is 100 percent,"
> Fenstersheib said.
> 
> County officials say they have no idea how many other people consumed the
> contaminated chili, which was cooked at about 2 p.m. Tuesday and was served
> to customers until the finger turned up at 7:20 p.m. Anyone who may have
> eaten the contaminated batch is encouraged to call county health officials
> at (408) 918-3400.
> 
> The finger was described by county Medical Examiner Dr. Joseph O'Hara as
> cooked but not decomposed. The digit was found in two pieces, a 1-inch
> fingertip complete with the skin whorls used in fingerprinting and a
> half-inch piece of fingernail. The digit appeared to have been torn off,
> possibly by manufacturing machinery, rather than cleanly cut.
> 
> Considering the nail's slightly longer length and neat grooming, O'Hara
> speculated that it may have belonged to a woman, though "it's hard to tell."
> 
> Since all of the workers at the restaurant were found to be in possession
> "of all 10 of their fingers," health inspectors assume the finger likely
> entered the food chain as a result of the manufacturing process, according
> to county Environmental Resources Director Ben Gale.
> 
> Health inspectors said the restaurant appeared to be generally clean and
> well-maintained, with only one minor violation having to do with a leaky
> vent. 
> 
> Gale said it could take weeks to track each of the numerous ingredients to
> their places of manufacture, which will be in different states or possibly
> even different countries. Since the law requires that industrial accidents
> result in a stoppage of the assembly line and be reported to authorities, it
> may be possible to pinpoint the site of the original accident.
> 
> In addition, authorities may be able to obtain a fingerprint and DNA from
> the finger to identify the person.
> 
> The restaurant was open Wednesday, and business was brisk despite the finger
> incident. 
> 
> Elizabeth Adcock, who visits that Wendy's frequently and was having a bowl
> of chili Wednesday at around 3 p.m., said she had heard television reports
> about the finger, but thought it might be an urban legend.
> 
> Another woman who was eating chili at the restaurant, San Jose State student
> Andria Mendoza, said she had overheard workers discussing a finger in
> Spanish, so she proceeded carefully.
> 
> "I actually did check -- with my spoon,'' she said.
> 
> Customer Gary Grant of San Jose expressed disappointment that it was
> business-as-usual at the restaurant.
> 
> "We come here all the time,'' Grant said. "We just ate here today, and
> nobody said a thing. There were no signs up.
> 
> "How can you trust somebody like that? You're still serving food. Which
> basically means you don't care.''
> 
> Customer Fernando Anaya was in a lighter mood.
> 
> "Where's the finger at?" he joked as he ordered a salad.
> 
> Anaya said he worked at a cannery many years ago, so the incident with the
> finger doesn't shock him. He said he plans to keep eating at his local
> Wendy's. 
> 
> "I don't eat chili anymore,'' he said. "I used to, but the cholesterol is
> too high." 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> Spazlist mailing list
> Spazlist@lists.spaz.org
> http://lists.spaz.org/mailman/listinfo.cgi/spazlist
> 

------ End of Forwarded Message

my favorite digital mistake is assigning the new song to the deck currently playing--OUCH 
talk about an abrupt mix
 
another great one is failing to heed the 45 on a drum&bass record and playing it at 33 after transitioning from a slower record. Trying to speed it up by hitting 45 either during a beatless breakdown or on 1 beat isn't fun. that's a pretty silly error that one has to be fairly drunk not to catch while cueing...although D&B at 33 can sometime sound like some nicely chilled nu-skool....
 
HA! fun thread this is
 


Amadu78 <amadu78@hotmail.com> wrote:
(lol) every one has done that one at least once

you know, i think i did this once before at a party.  it's so much 
worse than trainwrecking.  but you know, i think the whole house music 
dj dance thing wouldn't be so special and exciting if you didn't have 
some of the possibilities of bad things like trainwrecking or turning 
the wrong record player off ... one dj once told me he likes making it 
almost wreck to create tension ... and another dj once told me it's 
good to always feel a little tension.

if you can guess who these people are, i'll give you a free hug next 
time i see you.  and i'll give you a hint.  the first one is english, 
and the second one is american.

peace.deepfog

Carl Cox & Dan?

Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com> wrote:you know, i think i did this once before at a party. it's so much 
worse than trainwrecking. but you know, i think the whole house music 
dj dance thing wouldn't be so special and exciting if you didn't have 
some of the possibilities of bad things like trainwrecking or turning 
the wrong record player off ... one dj once told me he likes making it 
almost wreck to create tension ... and another dj once told me it's 
good to always feel a little tension.

if you can guess who these people are, i'll give you a free hug next 
time i see you. and i'll give you a hint. the first one is english, 
and the second one is american.

peace.deepfog

> seconds as i stood like a deer in headlights befaddled as to what just
> happened.

> done it at home. i've never done it playing out. finally!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJ Emile?

I've heard of him but not heard him. I saw virtually nada about him
during the short time I was in Phoenix but I heard of him years before
then because he was connected to the comic artist Jim Mahfood, who I
believe is now located in LA. And obviously to Z-Trip and Radar
(Bombshelter DJs). Odd that he won best rave dj or whatever according
to that article because Z-Trip and Radar are turntablists, so I always
assumed Bombshelter was a turntablist crew. Beyond that all I know
about him is what Jim Mahfood has written and drawn in his comics,
none of which is flattering, but all of which is entertaining.
(Apparently he was dating a stripper and he complained that he
couldn't jerk off any more because none of the porno chicks were as
hot as his girlfriend.)

Mahfood is also associated with hip-hop more than the rave scene,
although he is kinda well-known for his "anti-rave comic" which got
forwarded everywhere a few years back. It was the one with the ravers
complaining and bitching and whining and complaining about drama and
generally being hypocrites, saying things like "rave music isn't
pre-programmed beats for white people who can't dance! it isn't!" and
"I'm so disillusioned I'm going to throw a brick through the window of
Swell!" and "raves are for everybody! everybody who can afford $5
bottles of water, $20 tickets, and $200 pants!"

Mahfood is also, by the way, an awesome artist, who sent me comics for
free, and he has art for sale, right here:

http://www.40ozcomics.com/new/artforsale.html

And you should buy some. I'm gonna.

Anyway, basically all I know about Emile is that he was friends with
Mahfood and he sounded totally obnoxious. But in a good way. :-)


DJ Soundwave/Giles Goat Boy

Subject: Re: [sfraves] smack.you.upside.the.head.with.my.plur.stick

You should know by now I'm the last person you should be giving shit
to when it comes to that kinda stuff. I know you know better than to
assume that I'm some pussy-whipped raver who did too many drugs one
night.

I'm just telling you to grow up  and quit sounding like a fucking retard.

Jesus christ dude, cmon.

As for going soft, soft is most definitely not the word I'd use to
describe what going back to SF did for me. Moreso a spiritual release
than anything. Being stuck in the middle of the desert for 2 years
with no break has a tendency to beat the life out of you.

While you're off seeing the world, and taking an opportunity I will
not have for many years to explore. I've done nothing to attack you,
nor do I think I deserve to be spoken to in such a manner as you
currently are. I find it extremely rude and disheartening, and most
definitely don't appreciate it. Your actions dictate how others
perceive you, and right now, you're most definitely being perceived by
others as a real dick.

Also, one more thing: since you're talking so much about how you're
having so much fun travelling, and want to go back to new york after
you come back, why are you still on here, and for that matter, why are
you flaming people? You're basically starting the only drama I've seen
since re-joining the list a month ago. That's all I've gotta say, man.

I hope you enjoy seeing the world.

Golden rule, man. You get what you give.

You should know by now I'm the last person you should be giving shit
to when it comes to that kinda stuff. I know you know better than to
assume that I'm some pussy-whipped raver who did too many drugs one
night.

I'm just telling you to grow up  and quit sounding like a fucking retard.

Jesus christ dude, cmon.

As for going soft, soft is most definitely not the word I'd use to
describe what going back to SF did for me. Moreso a spiritual release
than anything. Being stuck in the middle of the desert for 2 years
with no break has a tendency to beat the life out of you.

While you're off seeing the world, and taking an opportunity I will
not have for many years to explore. I've done nothing to attack you,
nor do I think I deserve to be spoken to in such a manner as you
currently are. I find it extremely rude and disheartening, and most
definitely don't appreciate it. Your actions dictate how others
perceive you, and right now, you're most definitely being perceived by
others as a real dick.

Also, one more thing: since you're talking so much about how you're
having so much fun travelling, and want to go back to new york after
you come back, why are you still on here, and for that matter, why are
you flaming people? You're basically starting the only drama I've seen
since re-joining the list a month ago. That's all I've gotta say, man.

I hope you enjoy seeing the world.

Golden rule, man. You get what you give.

Here here now, Hell, If I was in Berlin, I sure as hell wouldn't be 
starting flame war threads on SFRaves... but then again, I'm not you, and 
you are not me, and you don't know me.

If I was in Berlin,  I'd be out enjoying the scenery.

You know Ryan, you've got *Way* too much time on  your hands for a world 
traveler, blah blah blah, and for someone who wanted to leave the SF Bay 
area, cause you hate it so much,  you sure put a lot of energy blowing 
smoke out of your ass... and flaming people and places around here like 
you are are all high and mighty.

As far as resources, whatever you want to believe, there's always a flip 
side to the coin...You seem to be stuck on the part that never lets go, 
of the idea that what you think you know is the complete truth. (Say, 
let's take my life and what really has been going on in it - you are not 
my friend - and at the rate at which you are chastising me - never 
will be.

As far as your beliefs are concerned, they don't compute. Your attempts to 
belittle me are so blase and unoriginal, not to mention, disrespectful and 
ignorant of my life at hand, at present, etc.

Hence, whatever you believe, just might not not compute....Regardless, 
this thread is starting to sound like it came from a bunghole...as far as 
your threats are concerned... Have a beautiful life, I'm not interested in 
what you have to say... never really was to begin with when you turned 
from someone with something intelligent to say to someone who thinks he 
knows it all. You definitely do not know me, and whatever you have to say 
is obviously tainted with your self-deprecating hate and repeated attempts 
to spread b$. Perhaps karma will come back to bite you in the ass some 
day.... be well and cheerios!

Spread love, fuck hate in the ass with a strap on...

<3 Karina

Subject: Re: [sfraves] smack.you.upside.the.head.with.my.plur.stick

is it just me or have we returned to the flame wars of old?  i
remember these popping up quite frequently the first couple years i
was on here.  not so much anymore.  except back then i kinda enjoyed
them, mostly because i didn't know the people involved!

but now i do know you guys and to be honest, i'd kinda rather not hear
this on SFR.  sure, i could just press delete, but i wanted to ask you
guys if you could either cool it down or just take it offline.  are
your personal differences really worth the drama of sending it out to
hundreds and hundreds of people?

some advice:

ryan, enjoy your travels.  my time spent living in china was a
fantastic experience that i'll never regret.  soak it in.  stop
looking at things from the perspective of an american.  stop trying to
compare things to what you're used to.   just try to see things as
they are and in the context from which they came.  enjoy life as a
human being.  i know taking this trip was a good decision for you.

karina, let it go and continue doing the things that you feel
passionate about.  don't get too caught up in other people's
criticisms and don't feel like you have to defend yourself.  don't
fight drama with drama.  it's really not worth it.

and to everyone else....PLUR!  ;)

-b

destination, but the path and journey I take - which has been much more 
colorful than you can even fathom.

for the record, enjoy your special K :) I've never been to rehab. Are you 
projecting your woes?

really aren't qualified to know what the hell you are talking about.

As far as IRC goes, again you have no clue. I'm not on IRC, haven't been 
in say fucking three plus years. You are so misinformed and so reaking 
lies / misinformation it is not even funny. You seriously have not let 
go of your personal attacks of me for years, if you have come so far in 
life, why don't you grow up and fucking move on?

I'm done with this thread, and you. Have a pleasant journey and may you be 
blessed with some happiness and better things to do in life than 
constantly comparing yourself to others, especially those you are truly 
ignorant of.

To the rest of the list, my apologies for this thread - Ryan hasn't 
dropped the attempt to be an asshole towards me for doing my job for as 
long as I've known of him on the list. My work and contribution speaks for 
itself. I wish the SFRaves community much love, and even to your antiplur, 
wish you well in life Ryan. Stop comparing yours to mine, we are not one 
and the same and never will be.

<3 Karina

> ------ Forwarded Message
> > From: jennifer blum <jen@5lowershop.org>
> > Date: Thu, 24 Mar 2005 10:34:11 -0800
> > To: "spazlist@spaz.org" <spazlist@spaz.org>
> > Subject: [SpAzLiSt] Wendy's diner finds human
> finger in her chili
> > 
> >
>
http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/03/24/MNGPUBU27R1.DTL
> > 
> > 
> > Wendy's diner finds human finger in her chili
> > 
> > Maria Alicia Gaura, Dave Murphy, Chronicle Staff
> Writers
> > Thursday, March 24, 2005
> > 
> > An unlucky diner bit into a segment of a human
> finger while digging into a
> > bowl of chili at a Wendy's restaurant in San Jose,
> Santa Clara County health
> > officials confirmed Wednesday.
> > 
> > The diner, who visited the restaurant Tuesday
> night, spit out the well-
> > cooked digit, notified restaurant workers and
> became sick to her stomach,
> > health officials said.
> > 
> > The origin of the finger remains a mystery.
> > 
> > Santa Clara County Health Officer Dr. Martin
> Fenstersheib said he was called
> > at home by San Jose police who went to Wendy's and
> immediately dispatched
> > health inspectors to the restaurant. He said he
> ordered officers to
> > transport the body part, wrapped in damp gauze, to
> the medical examiner's
> > office. 
> > 
> > The restaurant, at 1405 Monterey Road, was shut
> for a couple of hours while
> > the batch of chili and stocks of chili ingredients
> were impounded. The
> > restaurant was allowed to reopen and to cook
> another batch of chili using
> > newly purchased ingredients.
> > 
> > Wendy's officials said they are eager to find out
> how their food became
> > contaminated. 
> > 
> > "The entire investigation is with the county
> health department,'' said Steve
> > Jay, Wendy's marketing director for Santa Clara
> County. "We're fully
> > cooperating.'' 
> > 
> > Jay said the chili came from a master distributor
> but declined to name the
> > firm. He added that Wendy's has been doing
> business in the area for more
> > than 25 years and never had a serious problem
> before.
> > 
> > Fenstersheib said he spoke to the anxious woman
> several times by phone and
> > had the queasy experience of confirming to her
> that the object was
> > indisputably human. The woman asked officials not
> to name or even describe
> > her. 
> > 
> > "I had to confirm it to her that she had indeed
> put a piece of a human
> > finger in her mouth," Fenstersheib said. "She kind
> of lost it."
> > 
> > The woman was "emotionally distraught ... due to
> the unpleasant sensation of
> > having this (object) in her mouth," Fenstersheib
> said
> > 
> > He said the finger had been cooked at a high
> enough temperature to kill any
> > viruses, including hepatitis or HIV, and that it
> was very unlikely that she
> > will suffer any health effects from her
> experience, aside from psychological
> > trauma. 
> > 
> > "The potential for health impacts are extremely
> low for her or anyone else
> > who ate that chili," Fenstersheib said. He said,
> however, that he will
> > recommend baseline viral testing for the woman, to
> allow for comparison
> > should any food-borne illness emerge in the coming
> months.
> > 
> > A similar strategy might be wise for others who
> ate the contaminated food,
> > he said. "The risk is low, but nothing in medicine
> is 100 percent,"
> > Fenstersheib said.
> > 
> > County officials say they have no idea how many
> other people consumed the
> > contaminated chili, which was cooked at about 2
> p.m. Tuesday and was served
> > to customers until the finger turned up at 7:20
> p.m. Anyone who may have
> > eaten the contaminated batch is encouraged to call
> county health officials
> > at (408) 918-3400.
> > 
> > The finger was described by county Medical
> Examiner Dr. Joseph O'Hara as
> > cooked but not decomposed. The digit was found in
> two pieces, a 1-inch
> > fingertip complete with the skin whorls used in
> fingerprinting and a
> > half-inch piece of fingernail. The digit appeared
> to have been torn off,
> > possibly by manufacturing machinery, rather than
> cleanly cut.
> > 
> > Considering the nail's slightly longer length and
> neat grooming, O'Hara
> > speculated that it may have belonged to a woman,
> though "it's hard to tell."
> > 
> > Since all of the workers at the restaurant were
> found to be in possession
> > "of all 10 of their fingers," health inspectors
> assume the finger likely
> > entered the food chain as a result of the
> manufacturing process, according
> > to county Environmental Resources Director Ben
> Gale.
> > 
> > Health inspectors said the restaurant appeared to
> be generally clean and
> > well-maintained, with only one minor violation
> having to do with a leaky
> > vent. 
> > 
> > Gale said it could take weeks to track each of the
> numerous ingredients to
> > their places of manufacture, which will be in
> different states or possibly
> > even different countries. Since the law requires
> that industrial accidents
> > result in a stoppage of the assembly line and be
> reported to authorities, it
> > may be possible to pinpoint the site of the
> original accident.
> > 
> > In addition, authorities may be able to obtain a
> fingerprint and DNA from
> > the finger to identify the person.
> > 
> > The restaurant was open Wednesday, and business
> was brisk despite the finger
> > incident. 
> > 
> > Elizabeth Adcock, who visits that Wendy's
> frequently and was having a bowl
> > of chili Wednesday at around 3 p.m., said she had
> heard television reports
> > about the finger, but thought it might be an urban
> legend.
> > 
> > Another woman who was eating chili at the
> restaurant, San Jose State student
> > Andria Mendoza, said she had overheard workers
> discussing a finger in
> > Spanish, so she proceeded carefully.
> > 
> > "I actually did check -- with my spoon,'' she
> said.

Call you up in the middle of the night
Like a firefly without a light
You were there like a slow torch burning
I was a key that could use a little turning

So tired that I couldn't even sleep
So many secrets I couldn't keep
Promised myself I wouldn't weep
One more promise I couldn't keep

It seems no one can help me now
I'm in too deep
There's no way out
This time I have really led myself astray

CHORUS
Runaway train never going back
Wrong way on a one way track
Seems like I should be getting somewhere
Somehow I'm neither here no there

Can you help me remember how to smile
Make it somehow all seem worthwhile
How on earth did I get so jaded
Life's mystery seems so faded

I can go where no one else can go
I know what no one else knows
Here I am just drownin' in the rain
With a ticket for a runaway train

Everything seems cut and dry
Day and night, earth and sky
Somehow I just don't believe it

CHORUS

Bought a ticket for a runaway train
Like a madman laughin' at the rain
Little out of touch, little insane
Just easier than dealing with the pain

Runaway train never comin' back
Runaway train tearin' up the track
Runaway train burnin' in my veins
Runaway but it always seems the same

death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Seeking Bboys/Bgirls/Breakdancers 

Seeking B-Boys, B-Girls, Breakdancers, those who can Break for events

Are you familiar with the moonwalk, locking, popping, God-foot, floating, the 
Uprock, or other moves which continue the dance on the floor as a single 
rhythmic activity?

Do you know the moves of the Back Spin, Flip, Hand Spin, Head Spin, Windmill, 
Two Hand Stand, Head Wave, Worm Dances?

Can you rock it w/ the moves to break the beat including Top Rock, Turtle/Float 
Dance Styles, Six Step / Lower Footwork or the Back Spin methods?

A local collective of electronic musicians, producers, event planners and 
promoters spanning many genres of music including representation in the 
breaks & breakbeat genres of music are seeking talented professional / 
amateur bboys and bgirls to participate in events combining a mix of 
culture, rhythm, history, music, art and dance years in the making.

Please respond with your availability in coming months, what crew you are with 
/ if any, your contact information / website if available, age, location, the 
styles of breakdancing you are proficient with, contact information, and 
whether or not you'd be willing to donate your services and time for a return 
admission to the event / other forms of compensation including promotional 
freebies / music / etc.

Regards,

Karina

On Wed, 16 Mar 2005, Acid Totem wrote:

> Date: Wed, 16 Mar 2005 08:20:21 -0800
> From: Acid Totem <acidtotem@gmail.com>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: [sfraves] ACID TEST: Doc Martin Jeno Garth 4-22
> 
> ACID TEST reproduced by Acid Totem
>
> Friday, April 22, 2005 @ Club Mighty SF
>
> DOC MARTIN (sublevel)
>
> GARTH (wicked, grayhound)
>
> JENO (wicked, whoosh!)
>
> Ben Haus vs Dave L (acid totem)
>
> 10pm-4am
> 21+
> $5 b4 11pm
> $15 thereafter
>
> Presale tickets available at www.mighty119.com
>
> DRESS The Way YOU Are~
>
> www.mission-1.net
> 415 267-6172
>
>
> 1965, Ken Kesey, author of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", and his band
> of Merry Pranksters stage the first Acid Test; a radical and psychedelic
> experiment based around music and lighting projections in Santa Cruz County.
> Many Acid Tests would follow the Soquel Acid Test, and would prove to be a
> major catalyst of things to come in the counter-culture revolution of the
> 1960's. Circa 25 years later, a different revolution was occuring on the
> Beaches and in the Deserts of California. Under the watch of the full moon,
> DJ's such as Doc Martin, and Garth and Jeno of the Wicked Crew introduced
> House and Electronic music to thousands, and would lay the foundation for
> the West Coast Sound for the next decade plus.
>
> Join us as we celebrate all that is positive with the Old, the New, and
> everything in between. Re-experience the pure and virgin energy that helped
> create and build our House Nation.
>
>
> Stay tuned for Free Outdoor parties in the weeks before and after Acid Test
>
> http://www.mission-1.net/images/webflyer.gif
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MP3 recorders - line in - suggestions???



No, only certain Nomads do line in recording.  The 3 brands you want to
check out that have models with line-in recording are:

-Archos
-Nomad
-iRiver.

My friend just got an iRiver, its pretty hot. I have an Archos, and it
sounds good, but I have all sorts of problems with corrupt .mp3 files,
I would not recommend it.  Archos has this nice open-source alternative
software that I use, http://www.rockbox.org/, but it does not help
the .mp3 recording reliability much.

-troy

Bcc: 
Date: Mon, 28 Mar 2005 13:20:09 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 28 Mar 2005 20:20:09.0477 (UTC) FILETIME=[89E8AB50:01C533D3]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seeking Bboys/Bgirls/Breakdancers

I got this from answers.com



Toprock is a simple dance done standing up to initiate breakdancing. Its 
style is obvious to anyone watching, because it is incredibly unorthodox 
looking. Breakdancers take pride in having unique toprock that still stays 
within the definition of what toprock actually is.

Uprock is doing a toprock with someone else, sort of like a fight but 
without contact and very rhythmic. Uprocking is often confused with toprock, 
but the two are completely different dances

The basic 6-step resembles walking in a circle on the ground. Only one hand 
is touching the ground at a time. The 6-step is the building block for the 
rest of the dance, and is heavily 'teched' or modified to allow for 
variation and style.

Moonwalk: Many believe that the dance move made famous by Michael Jackson is 
called the moonwalk. In actuality, it is called the backslide. This is where 
a dancer slides backward while their legs appear to be walking forward. When 
a true moonwalk is performed, the dancer glides around on their feet in a 
similar way as a backslide, but travels in a circular, rather than linear, 
path. Mr. Wiggles, a famous hip-hop dancer, reiterates this difference 
during one of his instructional videos on gliding. This error in definition 
is not generally known to those outside of the breaking community.

The Worm: A move in which a dancer lies on the ground and forms a rippling 
motion through his body. This can be done if one of two ways, either forward 
or backwards, either shifting your weight from the upper body to the lower 
body (backwards) or vice-versa for forwards. Sophie Tucker is recognized as 
the creator of this move, which goes back to the 1920's. As this move is 
very old and very well known, even by those outside the breaking community, 
it is generally only performed when joking around and not in serious dance 
battles.

Headspin The dancer spins on his head, often while wearing a stocking cap, 
handkerchief, or even helmet. When the dancer uses his hands to aid in 
speeding up the spin, it is called 'tapping.' A dancer may tap for a few 
rotations and then 'glide' for as many as 15 rotations. Kid Freeze is the 
b-boy who claims to have invented the headspin.

Flare An incredibly difficult move borrowed from gymnastics and resembles 
the use of a Pommel Horse, but is performed without one.

Jackhammer A move performed on the ground, with the dancer balancing on one 
hand while laying his body on the elbow of the same arm. He then bounces up 
and down with his hand as he spins around.

Airflare An advanced move that is similar in theory to a flare or a 
windmill. While performing an airflare, the breaker is inverted with his 
torso at a 45 degree angle to the floor, his legs in a V-shape, and his arms 
straight. The hands are the only body part that touch the floor as the move 
is being performed. The bboy whips his legs, then arms around so that he 
travels in a circular path.

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.619.2)
X-ELNK-Trace: b815ca255710aa4c0ba167aeb931aee97e972de0d01da940226a6cf9367d878d9715599520bec704350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Originating-IP: 66.47.248.108
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MP3 recorders - line in - suggestions???

not sure if this would be overkill for your needs, but my 
recommendation is an Archos av320.  i swapped the hard drive for an 80 
gb - it was cheaper to do this than to buy the 80 gb model.

it records mp4 video, mp3 audio (up to 192kbps), or WAV (up to 48khz), 
and with the proper cable, can record digital (SPDIF) audio signal - 
great for dubbing from a DAT deck. also has USB 2.0, so file transfers 
are quick.

i lurve this thing - my only complaint is that the battery life is too 
short.

pxd

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Drug users flock to Easter parade
By Liam Houlihan, Melbourne Australia
29mar05

EVERY weekend one St Kilda car park is transformed into a bustling, 
open-air supermarket for illegal drugs.

The Herald Sun spent the early hours of Easter Saturday in the car park, 
while a dance party was going on next door at The Palace, and found it 
teeming with almost every kind of illicit drug.

In the space of two hours the Herald Sun witnessed:

GIRLS on the Esplanade openly handling ecstasy tablets.

OCCUPANTS of a car puffing on two "crack pipes" - glass devices used for 
smoking crack cocaine or a pure form of amphetamine called crystal meth.

TWO men using a rolled-up banknote to snort lines of white powder - either 
amphetamines or cocaine.

Early on Easter Saturday we were approached by two men, in a group of four, 
who tried to sell us ecstasy tablets.

"You want flippers?" one of them said. "Come on, you guys, I'll sell you 
flippers at the best price ever - two for $25."

Three of the four then posed for a photograph.

Ravers say drug dealers operate from their vehicles in the car park and can 
be found there like clockwork every Friday night for The Palace's weekly 
dance party, Bass Station.

They say it is an underground Melbourne institution that is as reliable as 
the McDonald's that is only a block or two away.

Dealers sold the dangerous drug GHB directly from their cars to those going 
to the indoor rave, ravers said.

One described it as just like having a hot-dog stand outside a pub.

"The ones that stay outside are the dodgy crew," said Jack, a 22-year-old 
hardcore house fan.

"If you've passed out a couple of times (on drugs), the club is not going 
to let you back in. The car park is for anyone that's really dodgy or 
hardcore. But drugs are quite prominent - buying and selling - inside the 
club, too."

On Saturday morning, some in the full car park did burnouts or danced as 
their car stereos blasted out techno music. Others smoked marijuana joints 
as they queued for tickets at the front of The Palace.

Jack said the concrete lot, which holds more than 200 cars, was the best 
place in Melbourne to go when you were stuck for drugs.

One raver, who called himself "Goat", wore a singlet that said: "Go Home G 
Heads" - a reference to users of GHB, a drug that many in the rave scene shun.

"I just don't like G," he said. "When people are on it, they sometimes 
can't stand up at all. Watching people just blow out on it - it's not good."

In February last year - before the widely publicised admission to hospital 
of 10 people at the Two Tribes rave - paramedics reported treating eight 
people found near the St Kilda car park for suspected overdoses.

Three of those required life support.

The same month, police swooped on the Jacka Boulevard car park and arrested 
five people for drug trafficking and possession offences.

More than 1200 ravers attended the bigger than usual Good Friday version of 
The Palace's weekly house music night.

Dozens more were turned away at the door. At 3.30am on Easter Saturday, the 
car park was still full.

Regulars of Bass Station said they were rarely, if ever, subjected to 
pat-down searches on entering the dance club.

http://www.thecouriermail.news.com.au/printpage/0,5942,12688042,00.html




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Depends on which SFR Party you are referring to:
If you want to join in on the planning effort for the SFRaves 13 Year 
Anniversary / or other collaborative events that SFRaves is working 
on as well, please join SFRaves Planners by sending an email to 
sfraves-planners-subscribe@hyperreal.org

<3 Karina

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Tue)

did i ever tell you about the time i had the first job i ever had?  well, this
was either the first or second job i had.  i was a singing telegram.  this
career was short-lived.  in fact, i'm not even sure why i took the job.  i
think i took it because i was so easily hired.  anyway, my first (and last)
assignment was to drive up to daly city in a chicken costume and sing "happy
bird-day" to someone.  well, i got to the block where it was, but i was looking
for the address and i set the chicken head down by my car to find the address.

well guess what happened?  yep, you guessed right!  i came back 5 minutes later
and the chicken head had disappeared!  i was so embarrassed that i drove back
to the place, and gave the costume back and told them i'd "be right back". 
well i never came back.  the lady called my house saying she was going to call
the police if i didn't return the head.  my dad ended up driving me up to
pacifica police department to file a police report.

so ends my first (i think) job).

today's quote i got from the movie "party monster" ... which is disturbing, but
a must see.  here's mcauley culkin to leave you cringing the rest of the day. 
by the way, he's not kidding about what he's saying!

--

"Oh James, I'm getting away with murder, and you're just jealous."

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Wushu from Hong Kong - this week

No, this is not music related at all, but I wanted to get the word out
about a few events this week.  As you may or may not know, I am an
avid practitioner of Chinese Wushu, a contemporary form of martial
arts.  This week, a team from Hong Kong is visiting the bay area and
will be doing several performances.

Even if you don't know what wushu is, you have most likely seen it
various movies, tv shows and commercials.  It is a dynamic and
beautiful art and sport and definitely worth checking out!  Here's the
info on the performances:

Asian Art Museum
200 Larkin Street
Martial Arts Demonstration with the Hong Kong Youth Wu Shu Troupe
Thursday, March 31
6:00 pm
Samsung Hall
Free with museum admission. Space is limited, and is offered on a
first-come, first-served basis. Free tickets will be distributed in
South Court starting at 5:00 pm on the day of the performance.


MACY'S
FRIDAY, APRIL 1ST
Wushu Demo - 12pm
Mens Bldg., Level 1
Come see the World Wushu Champions from Hong Kong as they perform the
Taiji, based on the Chinese philosophy of "Yin" and "Yang" as they
maneuver spectacular weapons used in ancient China like the dao and
the jian. These performers will illustrate the skill of co-operation
and coordination in the Chinese cultural legacy, Wushu.

and

Union Square Park
Saturday, April 2nd
Noon-2pm
They will be performing along with various dance and performance groups.

They will also be performing in the evening at the UC Berkeley Chinese
Martial Arts Tournament.  www.calwushu.com


To get an idea of what wushu is like, check out this video from a
recent youth competition in China:
http://www.fredenchine.com/fredenchine/martio3/art1/NationalJunior2005.zip


--

Subject: [sfraves] Ooooh KLP... My WR... Wow!!!

oh yeah... here's the thingie if U 4got:

KLP = Kinda Late Post
WR = Weekend Review

So like OK.. on Friday.. I was makin' plans w/ Mr Chessire 2 like do
someting.. originally, we were gonna have a BYOW here @ my pad, but I
dunno.. we couldn't musster enough people 2 come over... eh, oh well... so
yeah... there were these things I been seein' onine about a FMR goin' on &
I suggested it 2 him.. he was all down, so it was set.. we were gonna go 2
a Full Moon outdoor that night.. YAY...So Dope.. well.. almost!

So he comes by, picks me up, we make a pit stop in the City 2 my homie's
pad, then head out 2 the location.. Hello 2day.. LoL.. So Dope!  I mean..
OK.. we were like lost 4 like an hour & 1/2... it was kinda eh.. but
luckily, we found it!!  YAY!!

OK... it was Dope!!  DJ YAP was on decks when we got there & there was
some YUMMY Techno comin' outta the speakers!!  Heeeeeeeeeeello 2Day... he
played 1 of my most FAVE techno songs ever.... damn.. i shoulda looked on
the thingie 2 know what it was 'cause I always Love that tune whenever I
hear it!  I don't remember if there was another DJ who went on next, but
like after that, there was another DJ , Dom, who spun  this mad ummm.
well.. Goa-ish, Psy Trance-iah, acid-ie kinda music... when i asked him
what kinda trance was he spinning, he responded, "I was spinning
Trance?".. LMAO... OK.. then in closing.. Sticky served us a sunrise
helping of 80's stuff then Ghetto Tech... (It's nice day 4 a white
wedding).. So Dope!!!@  I swear man... I was buggin' so hard man!! 
Aaaawwwww Yeah!

It was nice 'cause it was the perfect gethering of Family in an intamite,
be it rowdy 80% of the time, setting... Hello 2day.. it was just perfect &
yeah.. a Good way 2 welcome spring 2 come in!  YAY!  I swear man.. I stil
get tingley just thinkin' about Friday night still...

Chessie.. I'm sooo glad U came out w/ me 2 that Homie!!  I promise we will
get shit strait w/ the *ahem* soon....  IB.. thank U 4 a Wonderful well...
dark 2 light morning & I Love U!  Can't wait 4 it again!


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> ObY {8O)
