Subject: [sfraves] (BSP) Cannabass 3/30 :: Koda : SIK : Dymphna

Wed 3/30

Koda
SIK
Dymphna

This wednesday come hear some down and dirty drums with bass to rattle
your soul. And don't forget the Cannabass drink specials:


$3 ALL DRAFTS
$3 MARGARITAS

Come get your drink on and your groove on while we're still charging no
cover.

Oh, BTW, 4/20 is on Wednesday this year. Keep on the lookout for a
slamming party that night!!!

--------------------------------

Every Wednesday

OPEN DECKS from 8p-10p. Get out of your bedroom and come play on a
professional sound system in an awesome booth. Bring your vinyl and/or
CDs, and your headphones and come grab a 1/2 hour slot. This is open to
ALL styles of music.

 From 10p-2a come hear weekly headliners, mostly Drum & Bass, but we mix
in some UK Grime, 2-Step, Hip Hop, Downtempo and other juicy sounds.
Featuring the Cannabass residents: Happy, Lewt, Spicious Taste and
Zigmund Void.

The Bench and Bar is a huge club in downtown Oakland, with a LOUD sound
system, large wooden dance floor, 3-mile long bar and a smoking patio.
It's just 2 Blocks from the 19th St BART Station.

21+ / No Cover
$3 ALL DRAFTS
$3 MARGARITAS

Bench and Bar
2111 Franklin St
Oakland, CA
510-444-2266

www.cannabass.com

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Community Mutiny and Masquerade Ball (Reclaim the
  Streets) 

--=====================_15617176==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

...please forward this email widely...

Please join us this Saturday for a comMUNIty mutiny -- a street party and
masquerade ball.  Experience the power of community, delight in the thrill
of an impromptu street party, revel in creative performances, art,
dancing, and music, all while taking a stand against the increasing
commodification of public space and public transportation, specifically
the proposed muni fare hike in San Francisco!  Reclaim the Streets
(RTS-SF) invites you to step off of that sidewalk...

   ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
    on this! SATURDAY April 2
    don't be late: meet up in DOLORES PARK @ NOON
    depart: to an UNDISCLOSED PARTY LOCATION @ 1 PM
    dress: to IMPRESS, as always...
           come in costume, and think 'masquerade ball'!
   ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

be creative:  bring your radio, skates, bicycle, kites, couches, astro
turf, little brothers, flowers, hula, hoops, boomboxes, ghettoblasters, D
and C batteries, sound systems, band, troupe, stunt, swimming pools,
trampolines, skate boards, guitars & drums, frisbees, soccer balls, chalk,
hammocks, trees, lemonade, sunblock, beach balls, banners, noisemakers,
instruments, puppets, urban redecoration toolkits, and of course your
friends.

be connected: this is important -- please add your CELLphone # to our
txt-mob!  we're gonna start using text messaging to help people find our
parties, and to communicate in the event that a party gets broken up.
its easy to join... [first register for an account at txtmob.com
(instructions on their site).  Once you are registered, you'll need to
sign up for the RECLAIMSF list.   scroll down the long list of groups
until you find our list, put a check in the box, then scroll all the way
down to the bottom of the page and click "submit".]

ways to help before Saturday:
- Print publicity from our website [www.reclaimsf.org] and put it up at
your work, home,  or wherever you hang out.
- Come to the final meeting Wednesday at 7:30 at the Village Market (18th
and Florida).  Bring any printed publicity that you have not yet put up. -
Mail sfrts@riseup.net if you have any questions, suggestions, plan to
perform, or want to help out in any way.

--
RTS is ART*DANCE*COSTUMES*SOUND SYSTEMS*PERFORMANCE*POETRY*LIVE
MUSIC*SPOKEN WORD*FREE FOOD*BYOB*RAIN OR SHINE*ALWAYS FREE* RTS IS
COMMUNITY * IT IS WHAT YOU MAKE IT!

www.reclaimsf.org




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MP3 recorders - line in - suggestions???

My friend has the iriver and thought it was pretty cool device.  He
did have some serious issues with levels though.  It's easy to clip on
the unit and end up with only static.  It would have been a better
unit if it showed you your levels.

Any idea if any of these do show your recording levels?


On Mon, 28 Mar 2005 14:54:49 -0800, Philip. X. Diaz
<st_indigo@earthlink.net> wrote:
> not sure if this would be overkill for your needs, but my
> recommendation is an Archos av320.  i swapped the hard drive for an 80
> gb - it was cheaper to do this than to buy the 80 gb model.
> 
> it records mp4 video, mp3 audio (up to 192kbps), or WAV (up to 48khz),
> and with the proper cable, can record digital (SPDIF) audio signal -
> great for dubbing from a DAT deck. also has USB 2.0, so file transfers
> are quick.
> 
> i lurve this thing - my only complaint is that the battery life is too
> short.
> 
> pxd
> 
> 
> On Mar 28, 2005, at 9:59 AM, Bam wrote:
> 
> > anyone own or have suggestions for MP3 players that can record a
> > line-in?
> >
> > trying to find something that i can record mixes on, record live

Message-ID: <20050331170748.17853.qmail@web60305.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 09:07:48 -0800 (PST)
From: georgeC | origami <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: tsheets@saturn5.com, "Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
Cc: The Twilight Laser Outpost <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: 6667
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MP3 recorders - line in - suggestions???

It's supposed to compete with things like a Zaxcom Deva and the Nagra
D, which are all 4+ track machines for location audio recording for
video production, and that cost $3K+..

There is that little handheld Edirol that does two channels and goes
for $4-500..  I think it has some sort of limiter function but I
haven't been able to scope out whether it is analog (useful) or digital
(not).

Then again, you could sit it on top of something like a Really Nice
Compressor by FMR Audio- a sub-$200, near-audiophile-quality compressor
that is about the size of a few cd jewel cases stacked up.  It does a
beautiful job of gracefully controlling clipping, if asked, and also
sounds great just for overall mix compression (try SuperNice mode!), if
you're into getting things a bit more balanced before they hit the
A/Ds- I know I am not yet a champ at matching levels track to track
when mixing records and cds..

For basic recording of live sets, there is an Ipod Shuffle-sized unit
called the Muvo Micro, by Creative, that has a stereo line in and costs
$150.  The sound quality is not supposed to be superlative, but for
simply documenting sets, sure is nice to have a solid-state thing the
size of a pack of gum to plop onto the mixer when you play out! :) 
Then get home, plug it in via usb, and shuttle the mp3 right off of the
thing.  Perty!

Cheers,
George

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: RIP Fred Korematsu

FRED KOREMATSU | 1919-2005

OAKLAND MAN'S STAND AGAINST CAMPS LED TO U.S. APOLOGY TO JAPANESE-AMERICANS

By Jessie Mangaliman and L.A. Chung

Mercury News

Fred Korematsu, the unassuming Oakland draftsman who unsuccessfully
challenged the detention of Japanese-Americans during World War II --
but was vindicated 40 years later -- died Wednesday of respiratory
failure at his daughter's home in Marin County.

Korematsu was 86.

``He had a very strong will,'' said Dale Minami, his friend and
attorney. ``He was like our Rosa Parks.''

To many Japanese-Americans and others, Korematsu was a civil rights
icon who risked not only the legal wrath of his own government, but
also the scorn of his own people when in 1944 he challenged the
internment of 120,000 Japanese-Americans.

Korematsu's stirring legal saga was the subject of an Emmy-winning PBS
documentary in 2002: Born in Oakland, he was one of four sons of
Japanese immigrants who owned a flower nursery. When ordered to go to
detention camp, Korematsu refused because he believed that Executive
Order 9066, signed by President Roosevelt, violated his constitutional
rights.

Korematsu, a 23-year-old welder at the time, went into hiding briefly,
altering his face with plastic surgery. He was soon arrested in San
Leandro.

In May 1942, he was convicted in federal court of violating the
presidential order. He appealed.

In the now-infamous 1944 case, Korematsu vs. United States, cited in
every constitutional law textbook, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that
the mass detention of Japanese-Americans was justified by national
security concerns.

At the time, it was a deep disappointment to young Korematsu. But some
Japanese-Americans thought he was unpatriotic. After losing the case,
Korematsu resigned himself to internment camp.

In 1982, three young Japanese-American lawyers in San Francisco
approached the feisty Korematsu and persuaded him to take his case
back to court. Minami, Karen Kai and Don Tamaki were energized by
their own parents and grandparents who had been interned.

The following year, Judge Marilyn Hall Patel of U.S. District Court in
San Francisco overturned Korematsu's conviction, citing government
misconduct through suppression, alteration and burning of evidence,
race discrimination, lack of military necessity, and manifest
injustice. ``We were not only trying to reverse a very bad legal
precedent,'' recalled Don Tamaki, ``but we were also trying to
vindicate our families.''

To Tamaki, ``the case represented the trials that Japanese-Americans
never had.''

``Fred was a giant in our community and a man who fought not only for
the civil rights for Japanese-Americans but for all Americans,''
Minami said. ``He took an unpopular stand at a time when the country
was in crisis. And he withstood criticism and ostracism 40 years
later.''

``There was truly an understanding that this case was a historic
one,'' said Kai, one of his other attorneys. ``It had tremendous
meaning on a personal level, but also in a much larger sense in terms
of constitutional law and civil rights.''

Korematsu's case paved the way for the landmark 1988 Civil Liberties
Act, when the U.S. government acknowledged that the detention of
Japanese-Americans was wrong, and apologized.

In 1998, President Clinton awarded Korematsu with the Presidential
Medal of Freedom, the country's highest civilian honor.

``In the long history of our country's constant search for justice,
some names of ordinary citizens stand for millions of souls -- Plessy,
Brown, Parks,'' Clinton had said. ``To that distinguished list today
we add the name of Fred Korematsu.''

Korematsu loomed large in the collective memory of young
Japanese-Americans like Chris Hirano, a director at the Japanese
Cultural and Community Center of Northern California.

``He's been incredibly inspiring,'' said Hirano. ``He epitomized
courage in the face of adversity.''

Hirano said he had spent some time with Korematsu. ``What I learned
from him is a lesson in simple philosophy of doing what's right,''
Hirano said, ``and in doing that, he changed the world.''

--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MP3 recorders - line in - suggestions???

Doesn't sound like it's too hot for recording, but it is cheap:

http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/03/24/review_creative_muvo_n200/

> Creative bundles a 2.5-to-3.5mm cable, allowing you to connect the N200
> to other audio/video kit and record their output direct to MP3. Encoding
> is limited to 96, 128 or 160Kbps.
>
> It's a slightly tricky system to use. You set the record level with the
> volume keys, though you can't adjust them once you've started encoding.
> And I found that while the music coming through the earphones sounded
> fine, it was too high for the encoder, causing the recorded sound to be
> clipped. You can get it right with some experimentation, but there are
> better ways of getting audio onto the device. That said, once you've got
> the record level right, the N200 is good at spotting the gap between
> tracks and creating a new file at each break.

From sfraves-return-120338-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Mar 31 18:08:02 2005

From: tsheets@saturn5.com
Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 10:07:59 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, scr@socal-raves.org
Message-ID: <20050331180759.GC19042@atari.saturn5.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
User-Agent: Mutt/1.5.6+20040907i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Moby gets skewered.



For some reason, I have always thought Moby to be a little dork.  I don't
know why.. something about his attitude always rubbed me the wrong way.
Becuase of this, I took some perverse pleasure by his latest album getting
totally skewered by the New York Times this morning:

--------

ALBUM REVIEW | MOBY


    What's Left After the End of Music

By KELEFA SANNEH
<http://query.nytimes.com/search/query?ppds=bylL&v1=KELEFA
SANNEH&fdq=19960101&td=sysdate&sort=newest&ac=KELEFA SANNEH&inline=nyt-per>

Published: March 31, 2005

In the late 1990's, Moby wasn't yet an ideology or a brand name or even
a pop star.

He was just a soft-spoken music geek, and he seemed likely to spend his
career enjoying the kind of underground fame that might ordinarily
attach to a punk rocker turned electronica producer turned eclecticist.
But then came "Play," in 1999, which laid scratchy old gospel and blues
samples over spotless new house music; nearly every track was soothing,
sort of melancholy, unexpectedly hummable. And soon Moby wasn't just a
musicmaker - he was a paradigm-shifter.

"Play" was an unexpected commercial success, even though the guy behind
it had neither a famous face nor a famous voice nor even, at first, a
famous song. Moby has been lodged in the celebrity constellation ever
since. His albums don't sneak into record shops anymore, they arrive -
or they are supposed to. This week, his new double CD, "Hotel" (V2),
makes its disappointing debut at No. 28 on the Billboard album charts.

How did "Play" make Moby a star in the first place? As most articles
about "Play" mentioned, Moby marketed his album by licensing the tracks
to commercials and soundtracks; relying on the power of corporate
synergy, he had made an end run around the pop establishment.

His wasn't just a success story, then, it was a new kind of success
story. Even better (according to the strange rules that governed 1999),
it was a success story involving the words "geek" and "synergy."
Suddenly, regular pop stars seemed old-fashioned: a bunch of oversized
personalities, jockeying for space on radio stations that broadcast
their songs using an antiquated system of frequency modulation. By
contrast, Moby was a scientist, a musical technician who listened to
everything and distilled what he heard into some state-of-the-art pop
essence.

"I want to have the broadest possible sonic palette to draw on when I'm
composing music," he told Gerald Marzorati of The New York Times
Magazine, adding that he'd been listening to "pop records, dance
records, classical records." And you could tell he felt a bit sorry for
those sad 20th-century types who confined themselves to a single genre.
He was a pop star for a world too sophisticated to believe in pop stars
- a post-pop-star, perhaps.

"The end of history will be a very sad time," the political theorist
Francis Fukuyama wrote in 1989, anticipating, after a fashion, Moby's
world. Mr. Fukuyama imagined a future defined by "economic calculation,
the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns, and
the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands." The appeal of Moby
was that he would give us a way to enjoy this future; he would satisfy
our "sophisticated consumer demands" through superior engineering.

In 2002, having picked up a few million new fans, Moby got a chance to
put this theory into practice with "18," and it was immediately clear
that something had gone wrong. In the liner notes, he opined, "One
problem in writing an essay for this record is that the circumstances of
the world are in such a state of flux," and many of the songs were just
as banal (and, somehow, as smug) as this bit of boilerplate.

Too sophisticated to believe in musical genres, Moby caricatured them
instead. "We Are All Made of Stars" had some vaguely new-wavey guitar, a
gentle backbeat and lyrics that aped the spaced-out platitudes of a bad
David Bowie song: "People they come together/People they fall
apart/Nothing can stop us now/'Cause we are all made of stars." From the
token hip-hop track ("Jam for the Ladies," which sounded a lot like the
Chemical Brothers) to the "Play"-ish "Sunday (the Day Before My
Birthday)" - which sounds less appealing, not more, when you learn that
Moby was born on Sept. 11 - the album showed the limits of pop as science.

Last year, Moby followed "18" with a stopgap techno album, "Baby Monkey"
(credited to his alter ego, Voodoo Child), which was meant as a lark but
sounded like an insult. He seemed to think he was a smart producer
dabbling in a dumb genre he had long since outgrown (he called the album
"very simple, melodic, electronic, dance music"), although the CD
swiftly disproved the notion that techno was easy.

And now comes "Hotel," packaged as a two-disc set: the album on one
disc, and a series of "ambient" remixes on a second. Again, there are
liner notes to guide us through the music. "I don't feel like making
music that is airless and lifeless because I also really like people and
the messy miasma of the human condition and I want to make messy, human
records that are open and emotional," he writes, as if this truism
unlocked a secret to music making.

More than ever, the focus here is on Moby as a singer and songwriter,
which is strange, because he is not very good at either job. In his
effort to leave generic constraints behind, he has drifted toward some
rather neutral variant of alternative-rock. In the lyrics, as in the
liner notes, he seems to mistake obviousness for truth: the lead single
is a mind-numbing song called, "Beautiful," where the romantic dialogue
consists largely of couplets like, "I love you baby/I love you now/I
love you baby/I love you now."

This music isn't just dull, though. Like much of what Moby has produced
since "Play," it's condescending, too. Much of it sounds like the work
of a producer who thinks pop music is supposed to be kind of idiotic,
and who thinks pop audiences should be glad that he deigns to give us
what we want. Do we like sex? O.K., here's "I Like It," four singularly
unpleasant minutes of heavy breathing. Do we like songs about how the
world is happy and sad and good and bad? O.K., here's "Slipping Away,"
with a wispy beat and Moby crooning, "Open to everything, happy and
sad/Seeing the good when it's all going . . ." - you can finish the
couplets yourself. And, knowing that we like familiarity, Moby has his
collaborator, Laura Dawn, sing a slowed-down version of the New Order
hit "Temptation."

Maybe this isn't really Moby's fault so much as it is ours. Like so many
other things in the late 1990's, his new paradigm seemed like a great
idea: car commercials were going to be the new pop songs and laptop
composers were going to be the new pop stars. But it turns out that we
really do like those oversized personalities who clog the radio stations
- some of whom even double as superior engineers.

Mr. Fukuyama, in his famous obituary, might have written (but didn't
quite, of course) that "boredom at the end of music will serve to get
music started once again." That's an appealing idea, but it's also
appealing to know, listening to "Hotel," that it won't be necessary. The
end of music seems to have ended itself.



--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: MP3 recorders - line in - suggestions???



Yep.. you can take it further too.  There are portable, battery-powered
A/D converters you can buy that output S/PDIF.  This way, you can bypass
your MP3 recorder's mediocore A/Ds and go right in digitally.  They
even have ones with 48V phantom power so you can hook up a mic directly.

Fun stuff on the cheap...

-troy

On Thu, Mar 31, 2005 at 09:07:48AM -0800, georgeC | origami wrote:
> It's supposed to compete with things like a Zaxcom Deva and the Nagra
> D, which are all 4+ track machines for location audio recording for
> video production, and that cost $3K+..
> 
> There is that little handheld Edirol that does two channels and goes
> for $4-500..  I think it has some sort of limiter function but I
> haven't been able to scope out whether it is analog (useful) or digital
> (not).
> 
> Then again, you could sit it on top of something like a Really Nice
> Compressor by FMR Audio- a sub-$200, near-audiophile-quality compressor
> that is about the size of a few cd jewel cases stacked up.  It does a
> beautiful job of gracefully controlling clipping, if asked, and also
> sounds great just for overall mix compression (try SuperNice mode!), if
> you're into getting things a bit more balanced before they hit the
> A/Ds- I know I am not yet a champ at matching levels track to track
> when mixing records and cds..
> 
> For basic recording of live sets, there is an Ipod Shuffle-sized unit
> called the Muvo Micro, by Creative, that has a stereo line in and costs
> $150.  The sound quality is not supposed to be superlative, but for
> simply documenting sets, sure is nice to have a solid-state thing the
> size of a pack of gum to plop onto the mixer when you play out! :) 
> Then get home, plug it in via usb, and shuttle the mp3 right off of the
> thing.  Perty!
> 
> Cheers,
> George
>

-----Original Message-----
From: tsheets@saturn5.com [mailto:tsheets@saturn5.com]=20
Sent: Thursday, March 31, 2005 10:08 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org; scr@socal-raves.org
Subject: [sfraves] Moby gets skewered.



For some reason, I have always thought Moby to be a little dork.  I
don't
know why.. something about his attitude always rubbed me the wrong way.
Becuase of this, I took some perverse pleasure by his latest album
getting
totally skewered by the New York Times this morning:

--------

ALBUM REVIEW | MOBY


    What's Left After the End of Music

By KELEFA SANNEH
<http://query.nytimes.com/search/query?ppds=3DbylL&v1=3DKELEFA
SANNEH&fdq=3D19960101&td=3Dsysdate&sort=3Dnewest&ac=3DKELEFA
SANNEH&inline=3Dnyt-per>

Published: March 31, 2005

In the late 1990's, Moby wasn't yet an ideology or a brand name or even
a pop star.

He was just a soft-spoken music geek, and he seemed likely to spend his
career enjoying the kind of underground fame that might ordinarily
attach to a punk rocker turned electronica producer turned eclecticist.
But then came "Play," in 1999, which laid scratchy old gospel and blues
samples over spotless new house music; nearly every track was soothing,
sort of melancholy, unexpectedly hummable. And soon Moby wasn't just a
musicmaker - he was a paradigm-shifter.

"Play" was an unexpected commercial success, even though the guy behind
it had neither a famous face nor a famous voice nor even, at first, a
famous song. Moby has been lodged in the celebrity constellation ever
since. His albums don't sneak into record shops anymore, they arrive -
or they are supposed to. This week, his new double CD, "Hotel" (V2),
makes its disappointing debut at No. 28 on the Billboard album charts.

How did "Play" make Moby a star in the first place? As most articles
about "Play" mentioned, Moby marketed his album by licensing the tracks
to commercials and soundtracks; relying on the power of corporate
synergy, he had made an end run around the pop establishment.

His wasn't just a success story, then, it was a new kind of success
story. Even better (according to the strange rules that governed 1999),
it was a success story involving the words "geek" and "synergy."
Suddenly, regular pop stars seemed old-fashioned: a bunch of oversized
personalities, jockeying for space on radio stations that broadcast
their songs using an antiquated system of frequency modulation. By
contrast, Moby was a scientist, a musical technician who listened to
everything and distilled what he heard into some state-of-the-art pop
essence.

"I want to have the broadest possible sonic palette to draw on when I'm
composing music," he told Gerald Marzorati of The New York Times
Magazine, adding that he'd been listening to "pop records, dance
records, classical records." And you could tell he felt a bit sorry for
those sad 20th-century types who confined themselves to a single genre.
He was a pop star for a world too sophisticated to believe in pop stars
- a post-pop-star, perhaps.

"The end of history will be a very sad time," the political theorist
Francis Fukuyama wrote in 1989, anticipating, after a fashion, Moby's
world. Mr. Fukuyama imagined a future defined by "economic calculation,
the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns, and
the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands." The appeal of Moby
was that he would give us a way to enjoy this future; he would satisfy
our "sophisticated consumer demands" through superior engineering.

In 2002, having picked up a few million new fans, Moby got a chance to
put this theory into practice with "18," and it was immediately clear
that something had gone wrong. In the liner notes, he opined, "One
problem in writing an essay for this record is that the circumstances of
the world are in such a state of flux," and many of the songs were just
as banal (and, somehow, as smug) as this bit of boilerplate.

Too sophisticated to believe in musical genres, Moby caricatured them
instead. "We Are All Made of Stars" had some vaguely new-wavey guitar, a
gentle backbeat and lyrics that aped the spaced-out platitudes of a bad
David Bowie song: "People they come together/People they fall
apart/Nothing can stop us now/'Cause we are all made of stars." From the
token hip-hop track ("Jam for the Ladies," which sounded a lot like the
Chemical Brothers) to the "Play"-ish "Sunday (the Day Before My
Birthday)" - which sounds less appealing, not more, when you learn that
Moby was born on Sept. 11 - the album showed the limits of pop as
science.

Last year, Moby followed "18" with a stopgap techno album, "Baby Monkey"
(credited to his alter ego, Voodoo Child), which was meant as a lark but
sounded like an insult. He seemed to think he was a smart producer
dabbling in a dumb genre he had long since outgrown (he called the album
"very simple, melodic, electronic, dance music"), although the CD
swiftly disproved the notion that techno was easy.

And now comes "Hotel," packaged as a two-disc set: the album on one
disc, and a series of "ambient" remixes on a second. Again, there are
liner notes to guide us through the music. "I don't feel like making
music that is airless and lifeless because I also really like people and
the messy miasma of the human condition and I want to make messy, human
records that are open and emotional," he writes, as if this truism
unlocked a secret to music making.

More than ever, the focus here is on Moby as a singer and songwriter,
which is strange, because he is not very good at either job. In his
effort to leave generic constraints behind, he has drifted toward some
rather neutral variant of alternative-rock. In the lyrics, as in the
liner notes, he seems to mistake obviousness for truth: the lead single
is a mind-numbing song called, "Beautiful," where the romantic dialogue
consists largely of couplets like, "I love you baby/I love you now/I
love you baby/I love you now."

This music isn't just dull, though. Like much of what Moby has produced
since "Play," it's condescending, too. Much of it sounds like the work
of a producer who thinks pop music is supposed to be kind of idiotic,
and who thinks pop audiences should be glad that he deigns to give us
what we want. Do we like sex? O.K., here's "I Like It," four singularly
unpleasant minutes of heavy breathing. Do we like songs about how the
world is happy and sad and good and bad? O.K., here's "Slipping Away,"
with a wispy beat and Moby crooning, "Open to everything, happy and
sad/Seeing the good when it's all going . . ." - you can finish the
couplets yourself. And, knowing that we like familiarity, Moby has his
collaborator, Laura Dawn, sing a slowed-down version of the New Order
hit "Temptation."

Maybe this isn't really Moby's fault so much as it is ours. Like so many
other things in the late 1990's, his new paradigm seemed like a great
idea: car commercials were going to be the new pop songs and laptop
composers were going to be the new pop stars. But it turns out that we
really do like those oversized personalities who clog the radio stations
- some of whom even double as superior engineers.

Mr. Fukuyama, in his famous obituary, might have written (but didn't
quite, of course) that "boredom at the end of music will serve to get
music started once again." That's an appealing idea, but it's also
appealing to know, listening to "Hotel," that it won't be necessary. The
end of music seems to have ended itself.



--=20

Subject: [sfraves] FnF camp fund-raiser auction - this saturday!

This Saturday, Friends & Family will be having a live auction and 
no-host cocktail party in SF to raise money for our 2005 Burning Man 
camp.

We'll be auctioning off services such as a 1 hour massage, a night of 
pampering, 2 hours of advanced Photoshop tutoring, a sailboat cruise 
around the bay, didjeridoo lessons, and menu planning and cooking 
services for a 4-person dinner party. All of the services have been 
graciously donated by members of the FnF community. Keep in mind that 
this is only a partial list of the auction items.

DJs for the evening (tentative):  Ethan, Danny Picard, Coldwar, Matt 
G., Indigo, and Dom Baranowski.

The event will take place at a location in San Francisco.  I regret 
that I can't post directions, but we have a very limited capacity.

Please contact me directly for more details.  Admission is free!

> the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns, and
> the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands." The appeal of Moby
> was that he would give us a way to enjoy this future; he would satisfy
> our "sophisticated consumer demands" through superior engineering.
> 
> In 2002, having picked up a few million new fans, Moby got a chance to
> put this theory into practice with "18," and it was immediately clear
> that something had gone wrong. In the liner notes, he opined, "One
> problem in writing an essay for this record is that the circumstances of
> the world are in such a state of flux," and many of the songs were just
> as banal (and, somehow, as smug) as this bit of boilerplate.
> 
> Too sophisticated to believe in musical genres, Moby caricatured them
> instead. "We Are All Made of Stars" had some vaguely new-wavey guitar, a
> gentle backbeat and lyrics that aped the spaced-out platitudes of a bad
> David Bowie song: "People they come together/People they fall
> apart/Nothing can stop us now/'Cause we are all made of stars." From the
> token hip-hop track ("Jam for the Ladies," which sounded a lot like the
> Chemical Brothers) to the "Play"-ish "Sunday (the Day Before My
> Birthday)" - which sounds less appealing, not more, when you learn that
> Moby was born on Sept. 11 - the album showed the limits of pop as
> science.
> 
> Last year, Moby followed "18" with a stopgap techno album, "Baby Monkey"
> (credited to his alter ego, Voodoo Child), which was meant as a lark but
> sounded like an insult. He seemed to think he was a smart producer
> dabbling in a dumb genre he had long since outgrown (he called the album
> "very simple, melodic, electronic, dance music"), although the CD
> swiftly disproved the notion that techno was easy.
> 
> And now comes "Hotel," packaged as a two-disc set: the album on one
> disc, and a series of "ambient" remixes on a second. Again, there are
> liner notes to guide us through the music. "I don't feel like making
> music that is airless and lifeless because I also really like people and
> the messy miasma of the human condition and I want to make messy, human
> records that are open and emotional," he writes, as if this truism
> unlocked a secret to music making.
> 
> More than ever, the focus here is on Moby as a singer and songwriter,
> which is strange, because he is not very good at either job. In his
> effort to leave generic constraints behind, he has drifted toward some
> rather neutral variant of alternative-rock. In the lyrics, as in the
> liner notes, he seems to mistake obviousness for truth: the lead single
> is a mind-numbing song called, "Beautiful," where the romantic dialogue
> consists largely of couplets like, "I love you baby/I love you now/I
> love you baby/I love you now."
> 
> This music isn't just dull, though. Like much of what Moby has produced
> since "Play," it's condescending, too. Much of it sounds like the work
> of a producer who thinks pop music is supposed to be kind of idiotic,
> and who thinks pop audiences should be glad that he deigns to give us
> what we want. Do we like sex? O.K., here's "I Like It," four singularly
> unpleasant minutes of heavy breathing. Do we like songs about how the
> world is happy and sad and good and bad? O.K., here's "Slipping Away,"
> with a wispy beat and Moby crooning, "Open to everything, happy and
> sad/Seeing the good when it's all going . . ." - you can finish the
> couplets yourself. And, knowing that we like familiarity, Moby has his
> collaborator, Laura Dawn, sing a slowed-down version of the New Order
> hit "Temptation."
> 
> Maybe this isn't really Moby's fault so much as it is ours. Like so many
> other things in the late 1990's, his new paradigm seemed like a great
> idea: car commercials were going to be the new pop songs and laptop
> composers were going to be the new pop stars. But it turns out that we
> really do like those oversized personalities who clog the radio stations
> - some of whom even double as superior engineers.
> 
> Mr. Fukuyama, in his famous obituary, might have written (but didn't
> quite, of course) that "boredom at the end of music will serve to get
> music started once again." That's an appealing idea, but it's also
> appealing to know, listening to "Hotel," that it won't be necessary. The
> end of music seems to have ended itself.
> 
> 
> 
> -- 
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------

> tsheets@saturn5.com                                  <- You have found
> me   
> http://www.ferrapsylix.com                           <- sub atomic
> breakbeat
> "I just don't have the discipline to be a hippie"    <- Homer J. Simpson
>

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

On Thu, Mar 31, 2005 at 10:26:11AM -0800, Steve Osteen wrote:
> That's a great article! Too bad it is associated with such a crappy
> periodical.
>=20
>=20
> -----Original Message-----
> From: tsheets@saturn5.com [mailto:tsheets@saturn5.com]=20
> Sent: Thursday, March 31, 2005 10:08 AM
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org; scr@socal-raves.org
> Subject: [sfraves] Moby gets skewered.
>=20
>=20
>=20
> For some reason, I have always thought Moby to be a little dork.  I
> don't
> know why.. something about his attitude always rubbed me the wrong
way.
> Becuase of this, I took some perverse pleasure by his latest album
> getting
> totally skewered by the New York Times this morning:
>=20
> --------
>=20
> ALBUM REVIEW | MOBY
>=20
>=20
>     What's Left After the End of Music
>=20
> By KELEFA SANNEH
> <http://query.nytimes.com/search/query?ppds=3DbylL&v1=3DKELEFA
> SANNEH&fdq=3D19960101&td=3Dsysdate&sort=3Dnewest&ac=3DKELEFA
> SANNEH&inline=3Dnyt-per>
>=20
> Published: March 31, 2005
>=20
> In the late 1990's, Moby wasn't yet an ideology or a brand name or
even
> a pop star.
>=20
> He was just a soft-spoken music geek, and he seemed likely to spend
his
> career enjoying the kind of underground fame that might ordinarily
> attach to a punk rocker turned electronica producer turned
eclecticist.
> But then came "Play," in 1999, which laid scratchy old gospel and
blues
> samples over spotless new house music; nearly every track was
soothing,
> sort of melancholy, unexpectedly hummable. And soon Moby wasn't just a
> musicmaker - he was a paradigm-shifter.
>=20
> "Play" was an unexpected commercial success, even though the guy
behind
> it had neither a famous face nor a famous voice nor even, at first, a
> famous song. Moby has been lodged in the celebrity constellation ever
> since. His albums don't sneak into record shops anymore, they arrive -
> or they are supposed to. This week, his new double CD, "Hotel" (V2),
> makes its disappointing debut at No. 28 on the Billboard album charts.
>=20
> How did "Play" make Moby a star in the first place? As most articles
> about "Play" mentioned, Moby marketed his album by licensing the
tracks
> to commercials and soundtracks; relying on the power of corporate
> synergy, he had made an end run around the pop establishment.
>=20
> His wasn't just a success story, then, it was a new kind of success
> story. Even better (according to the strange rules that governed
1999),
> it was a success story involving the words "geek" and "synergy."
> Suddenly, regular pop stars seemed old-fashioned: a bunch of oversized
> personalities, jockeying for space on radio stations that broadcast
> their songs using an antiquated system of frequency modulation. By
> contrast, Moby was a scientist, a musical technician who listened to
> everything and distilled what he heard into some state-of-the-art pop
> essence.
>=20
> "I want to have the broadest possible sonic palette to draw on when
I'm
> composing music," he told Gerald Marzorati of The New York Times
> Magazine, adding that he'd been listening to "pop records, dance
> records, classical records." And you could tell he felt a bit sorry
for
> those sad 20th-century types who confined themselves to a single
genre.
> He was a pop star for a world too sophisticated to believe in pop
stars
> - a post-pop-star, perhaps.
>=20
> "The end of history will be a very sad time," the political theorist
> Francis Fukuyama wrote in 1989, anticipating, after a fashion, Moby's
> world. Mr. Fukuyama imagined a future defined by "economic
calculation,
> the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns, and
> the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands." The appeal of
Moby
> was that he would give us a way to enjoy this future; he would satisfy
> our "sophisticated consumer demands" through superior engineering.
>=20
> In 2002, having picked up a few million new fans, Moby got a chance to
> put this theory into practice with "18," and it was immediately clear
> that something had gone wrong. In the liner notes, he opined, "One
> problem in writing an essay for this record is that the circumstances
of
> the world are in such a state of flux," and many of the songs were
just
> as banal (and, somehow, as smug) as this bit of boilerplate.
>=20
> Too sophisticated to believe in musical genres, Moby caricatured them
> instead. "We Are All Made of Stars" had some vaguely new-wavey guitar,
a
> gentle backbeat and lyrics that aped the spaced-out platitudes of a
bad
> David Bowie song: "People they come together/People they fall
> apart/Nothing can stop us now/'Cause we are all made of stars." From
the
> token hip-hop track ("Jam for the Ladies," which sounded a lot like
the
> Chemical Brothers) to the "Play"-ish "Sunday (the Day Before My
> Birthday)" - which sounds less appealing, not more, when you learn
that
> Moby was born on Sept. 11 - the album showed the limits of pop as
> science.
>=20
> Last year, Moby followed "18" with a stopgap techno album, "Baby
Monkey"
> (credited to his alter ego, Voodoo Child), which was meant as a lark
but
> sounded like an insult. He seemed to think he was a smart producer
> dabbling in a dumb genre he had long since outgrown (he called the
album
> "very simple, melodic, electronic, dance music"), although the CD
> swiftly disproved the notion that techno was easy.
>=20
> And now comes "Hotel," packaged as a two-disc set: the album on one
> disc, and a series of "ambient" remixes on a second. Again, there are
> liner notes to guide us through the music. "I don't feel like making
> music that is airless and lifeless because I also really like people
and
> the messy miasma of the human condition and I want to make messy,
human
> records that are open and emotional," he writes, as if this truism
> unlocked a secret to music making.
>=20
> More than ever, the focus here is on Moby as a singer and songwriter,
> which is strange, because he is not very good at either job. In his
> effort to leave generic constraints behind, he has drifted toward some
> rather neutral variant of alternative-rock. In the lyrics, as in the
> liner notes, he seems to mistake obviousness for truth: the lead
single
> is a mind-numbing song called, "Beautiful," where the romantic
dialogue
> consists largely of couplets like, "I love you baby/I love you now/I
> love you baby/I love you now."
>=20
> This music isn't just dull, though. Like much of what Moby has
produced
> since "Play," it's condescending, too. Much of it sounds like the work
> of a producer who thinks pop music is supposed to be kind of idiotic,
> and who thinks pop audiences should be glad that he deigns to give us
> what we want. Do we like sex? O.K., here's "I Like It," four
singularly
> unpleasant minutes of heavy breathing. Do we like songs about how the
> world is happy and sad and good and bad? O.K., here's "Slipping Away,"
> with a wispy beat and Moby crooning, "Open to everything, happy and
> sad/Seeing the good when it's all going . . ." - you can finish the
> couplets yourself. And, knowing that we like familiarity, Moby has his
> collaborator, Laura Dawn, sing a slowed-down version of the New Order
> hit "Temptation."
>=20
> Maybe this isn't really Moby's fault so much as it is ours. Like so
many
> other things in the late 1990's, his new paradigm seemed like a great
> idea: car commercials were going to be the new pop songs and laptop
> composers were going to be the new pop stars. But it turns out that we
> really do like those oversized personalities who clog the radio
stations
> - some of whom even double as superior engineers.
>=20
> Mr. Fukuyama, in his famous obituary, might have written (but didn't
> quite, of course) that "boredom at the end of music will serve to get
> music started once again." That's an appealing idea, but it's also
> appealing to know, listening to "Hotel," that it won't be necessary.
The
> end of music seems to have ended itself.
>=20
>=20
>=20

> > of a producer who thinks pop music is supposed to be kind of idiotic,
> > and who thinks pop audiences should be glad that he deigns to give us
> > what we want. Do we like sex? O.K., here's "I Like It," four
> singularly
> > unpleasant minutes of heavy breathing. Do we like songs about how the
> > world is happy and sad and good and bad? O.K., here's "Slipping Away,"
> > with a wispy beat and Moby crooning, "Open to everything, happy and
> > sad/Seeing the good when it's all going . . ." - you can finish the
> > couplets yourself. And, knowing that we like familiarity, Moby has his
> > collaborator, Laura Dawn, sing a slowed-down version of the New Order
> > hit "Temptation."
> > 
> > Maybe this isn't really Moby's fault so much as it is ours. Like so
> many
> > other things in the late 1990's, his new paradigm seemed like a great
> > idea: car commercials were going to be the new pop songs and laptop
> > composers were going to be the new pop stars. But it turns out that we
> > really do like those oversized personalities who clog the radio
> stations
> > - some of whom even double as superior engineers.
> > 
> > Mr. Fukuyama, in his famous obituary, might have written (but didn't
> > quite, of course) that "boredom at the end of music will serve to get
> > music started once again." That's an appealing idea, but it's also
> > appealing to know, listening to "Hotel," that it won't be necessary.
> The
> > end of music seems to have ended itself.
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > -- 
> >

> > me

> > career enjoying the kind of underground fame that might ordinarily
> > attach to a punk rocker turned electronica producer turned
> eclecticist.
> > But then came "Play," in 1999, which laid scratchy old gospel and
> blues
> > samples over spotless new house music; nearly every track was
> soothing,
> > sort of melancholy, unexpectedly hummable. And soon Moby wasn't just
a
> > musicmaker - he was a paradigm-shifter.
> >=20
> > "Play" was an unexpected commercial success, even though the guy
> behind
> > it had neither a famous face nor a famous voice nor even, at first,
a
> > famous song. Moby has been lodged in the celebrity constellation
ever
> > since. His albums don't sneak into record shops anymore, they arrive
-
> > or they are supposed to. This week, his new double CD, "Hotel" (V2),
> > makes its disappointing debut at No. 28 on the Billboard album
charts.
> >=20
> > How did "Play" make Moby a star in the first place? As most articles
> > about "Play" mentioned, Moby marketed his album by licensing the
> tracks
> > to commercials and soundtracks; relying on the power of corporate
> > synergy, he had made an end run around the pop establishment.
> >=20
> > His wasn't just a success story, then, it was a new kind of success
> > story. Even better (according to the strange rules that governed
> 1999),
> > it was a success story involving the words "geek" and "synergy."
> > Suddenly, regular pop stars seemed old-fashioned: a bunch of
oversized
> > personalities, jockeying for space on radio stations that broadcast
> > their songs using an antiquated system of frequency modulation. By
> > contrast, Moby was a scientist, a musical technician who listened to
> > everything and distilled what he heard into some state-of-the-art
pop
> > essence.
> >=20
> > "I want to have the broadest possible sonic palette to draw on when
> I'm
> > composing music," he told Gerald Marzorati of The New York Times
> > Magazine, adding that he'd been listening to "pop records, dance
> > records, classical records." And you could tell he felt a bit sorry
> for
> > those sad 20th-century types who confined themselves to a single
> genre.
> > He was a pop star for a world too sophisticated to believe in pop
> stars
> > - a post-pop-star, perhaps.
> >=20
> > "The end of history will be a very sad time," the political theorist
> > Francis Fukuyama wrote in 1989, anticipating, after a fashion,
Moby's
> > world. Mr. Fukuyama imagined a future defined by "economic
> calculation,
> > the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns,
and
> > the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands." The appeal of
> Moby
> > was that he would give us a way to enjoy this future; he would
satisfy
> > our "sophisticated consumer demands" through superior engineering.
> >=20
> > In 2002, having picked up a few million new fans, Moby got a chance
to
> > put this theory into practice with "18," and it was immediately
clear
> > that something had gone wrong. In the liner notes, he opined, "One
> > problem in writing an essay for this record is that the
circumstances
> of
> > the world are in such a state of flux," and many of the songs were
> just
> > as banal (and, somehow, as smug) as this bit of boilerplate.
> >=20
> > Too sophisticated to believe in musical genres, Moby caricatured
them
> > instead. "We Are All Made of Stars" had some vaguely new-wavey
guitar,
> a
> > gentle backbeat and lyrics that aped the spaced-out platitudes of a
> bad
> > David Bowie song: "People they come together/People they fall
> > apart/Nothing can stop us now/'Cause we are all made of stars." From
> the
> > token hip-hop track ("Jam for the Ladies," which sounded a lot like
> the
> > Chemical Brothers) to the "Play"-ish "Sunday (the Day Before My
> > Birthday)" - which sounds less appealing, not more, when you learn
> that
> > Moby was born on Sept. 11 - the album showed the limits of pop as
> > science.
> >=20
> > Last year, Moby followed "18" with a stopgap techno album, "Baby
> Monkey"
> > (credited to his alter ego, Voodoo Child), which was meant as a lark
> but
> > sounded like an insult. He seemed to think he was a smart producer
> > dabbling in a dumb genre he had long since outgrown (he called the
> album
> > "very simple, melodic, electronic, dance music"), although the CD
> > swiftly disproved the notion that techno was easy.
> >=20
> > And now comes "Hotel," packaged as a two-disc set: the album on one
> > disc, and a series of "ambient" remixes on a second. Again, there
are
> > liner notes to guide us through the music. "I don't feel like making
> > music that is airless and lifeless because I also really like people
> and
> > the messy miasma of the human condition and I want to make messy,
> human
> > records that are open and emotional," he writes, as if this truism
> > unlocked a secret to music making.
> >=20
> > More than ever, the focus here is on Moby as a singer and
songwriter,
> > which is strange, because he is not very good at either job. In his
> > effort to leave generic constraints behind, he has drifted toward
some
> > rather neutral variant of alternative-rock. In the lyrics, as in the
> > liner notes, he seems to mistake obviousness for truth: the lead
> single
> > is a mind-numbing song called, "Beautiful," where the romantic
> dialogue
> > consists largely of couplets like, "I love you baby/I love you now/I
> > love you baby/I love you now."
> >=20
> > This music isn't just dull, though. Like much of what Moby has
> produced
> > since "Play," it's condescending, too. Much of it sounds like the
work
> > of a producer who thinks pop music is supposed to be kind of
idiotic,
> > and who thinks pop audiences should be glad that he deigns to give
us
> > what we want. Do we like sex? O.K., here's "I Like It," four
> singularly
> > unpleasant minutes of heavy breathing. Do we like songs about how
the
> > world is happy and sad and good and bad? O.K., here's "Slipping
Away,"
> > with a wispy beat and Moby crooning, "Open to everything, happy and
> > sad/Seeing the good when it's all going . . ." - you can finish the
> > couplets yourself. And, knowing that we like familiarity, Moby has
his
> > collaborator, Laura Dawn, sing a slowed-down version of the New
Order
> > hit "Temptation."
> >=20
> > Maybe this isn't really Moby's fault so much as it is ours. Like so
> many
> > other things in the late 1990's, his new paradigm seemed like a
great
> > idea: car commercials were going to be the new pop songs and laptop
> > composers were going to be the new pop stars. But it turns out that
we
> > really do like those oversized personalities who clog the radio
> stations
> > - some of whom even double as superior engineers.
> >=20
> > Mr. Fukuyama, in his famous obituary, might have written (but didn't
> > quite, of course) that "boredom at the end of music will serve to
get
> > music started once again." That's an appealing idea, but it's also
> > appealing to know, listening to "Hotel," that it won't be necessary.
> The
> > end of music seems to have ended itself.
> >=20
> >=20
> >=20

Subject: [sfraves] more auction items

Here's an updated list of auction items for the FnF Burning Man Camp 
Fundraiser this Saturday:


1) 2 hours of intermediate/advanced Photoshop lessons from a guy who 
really know
his skills. He can teach you tricks of the trade and how to achieve 
those
techniques you've always wondered about.

2) Up to four hours of Photography work. Either lessons and/or 
shooting. This
could include company photos, family photos, art photos, sexy shots to 
give your
loved one, or maybe just the ego boost of the best photo you've ever 
had taken of
yourself.

3) "Night of the 7 Veils" This is an evening of Moroccan luxury. 
Dinner, belly
dancing, massage, pampering. This item can accommodate up to six people.

4) Video Services. This can include shooting, editing or tutoring Final 
Cut Pro.

5) Sewing Lessons from one of the CFDC Fashion Show renowned designers.

6) 1.5 hours massage, energy work, meditation and/or reiki - sure to 
send you into
outer bliss.

7) DJ services for your party or bar mitzvah

8) Two Didgeridoo Lessons. How often does this come up? And if you 
don't own your
own didge, one will be provided for you. So cool.

9) Guitar Lessons. Acoustic or rock - your choice. Two lessons included 
in this item.

10) Two hours of Graphic/Web Design work. I know some of you could use 
updates to your web site.
Now's the time to do it!

11) Super-Basic Loop & Sample Recording Lesson - want to compose 
electronica? Have
zero musical skills? Cool!! Using Acid and SoundForge, you will learn 
how to make
a smokin' track out of loops and samples from your own records!

12) Scrabble Lesson from a pro who used to play on the tournament 
circuit and
national championships. He can show you how to blow your friends off 
the board!

13) A trip on a 36' Sailboat around the bay for a group of up to 5 
people. The
boat has a bathroom on it, downstairs cabin with 5 beds, icebox and 
stove. Lunch
will be included in the trip. Typical trips around the bay are 6 hours. 
What a
great way to spend a perfect day.

14) Want to relax? Well then, bid on a 1 hour massage with a butterfly 
who's touch
will surely make you forget your own name.

15) Cooking/shopping lesson for a gourmet Vegan meal. We've all wanted 
to learn to
eat healthier, but don't know where to begin. Well here's your chance 
to learn
with someone who's had lots of experience making some of the best food 
this side
of the hemisphere!

16) A night on the town complete with Limo, Champagne and all the 
catering
amenities. This item can accommodate up to four people.

We will be able to take payment installments on any of the higher 
priced items.
We will also be accepting paypal and checks.

simply means, "Republican who thinks they'd be run out of town on a

this list has been firmly, resolutely right-wing.

anything wrong with my being a tofu-toting, organic-veggie-worshipping,
hippie-parents-having bleeding heart.

with politics either. It is MY OWM opinion that the newspaper sucks
because most articles I've read from it don't use proper journalistic
ethics.

So, you and Troy can get off my case and go fuck off now.

I don't understand why you guys are such assholes around here.

From sfraves-return-120358-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Mar 31 22:08:59 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-120358-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 62367 invoked from network); 31 Mar 2005 22:08:59 -0000
Message-ID: <BAY21-F5005F65C482C4BCC652BF85470@phx.gbl>
X-Originating-IP: [24.23.138.119]
X-Originating-Email: [electrofunk138@hotmail.com]

Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 14:08:56 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 31 Mar 2005 22:08:56.0526 (UTC) FILETIME=[3B928EE0:01C5363E]

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Moby gets skewered.

>From: tsheets@saturn5.com
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, scr@socal-raves.org
>Subject: [sfraves] Moby gets skewered.
>Date: Thu, 31 Mar 2005 10:07:59 -0800
>
>
>
>For some reason, I have always thought Moby to be a little dork.  I don't
>know why.. something about his attitude always rubbed me the wrong way.
>Becuase of this, I took some perverse pleasure by his latest album getting
>totally skewered by the New York Times this morning:
>
>--------
>
>ALBUM REVIEW | MOBY
>
>
>     What's Left After the End of Music
>
>By KELEFA SANNEH
><http://query.nytimes.com/search/query?ppds=bylL&v1=KELEFA
>SANNEH&fdq=19960101&td=sysdate&sort=newest&ac=KELEFA SANNEH&inline=nyt-per>
>
>Published: March 31, 2005
>
>In the late 1990's, Moby wasn't yet an ideology or a brand name or even
>a pop star.
>
>He was just a soft-spoken music geek, and he seemed likely to spend his
>career enjoying the kind of underground fame that might ordinarily
>attach to a punk rocker turned electronica producer turned eclecticist.
>But then came "Play," in 1999, which laid scratchy old gospel and blues
>samples over spotless new house music; nearly every track was soothing,
>sort of melancholy, unexpectedly hummable. And soon Moby wasn't just a
>musicmaker - he was a paradigm-shifter.
>
>"Play" was an unexpected commercial success, even though the guy behind
>it had neither a famous face nor a famous voice nor even, at first, a
>famous song. Moby has been lodged in the celebrity constellation ever
>since. His albums don't sneak into record shops anymore, they arrive -
>or they are supposed to. This week, his new double CD, "Hotel" (V2),
>makes its disappointing debut at No. 28 on the Billboard album charts.
>
>How did "Play" make Moby a star in the first place? As most articles
>about "Play" mentioned, Moby marketed his album by licensing the tracks
>to commercials and soundtracks; relying on the power of corporate
>synergy, he had made an end run around the pop establishment.
>
>His wasn't just a success story, then, it was a new kind of success
>story. Even better (according to the strange rules that governed 1999),
>it was a success story involving the words "geek" and "synergy."
>Suddenly, regular pop stars seemed old-fashioned: a bunch of oversized
>personalities, jockeying for space on radio stations that broadcast
>their songs using an antiquated system of frequency modulation. By
>contrast, Moby was a scientist, a musical technician who listened to
>everything and distilled what he heard into some state-of-the-art pop
>essence.
>
>"I want to have the broadest possible sonic palette to draw on when I'm
>composing music," he told Gerald Marzorati of The New York Times
>Magazine, adding that he'd been listening to "pop records, dance
>records, classical records." And you could tell he felt a bit sorry for
>those sad 20th-century types who confined themselves to a single genre.
>He was a pop star for a world too sophisticated to believe in pop stars
>- a post-pop-star, perhaps.
>
>"The end of history will be a very sad time," the political theorist
>Francis Fukuyama wrote in 1989, anticipating, after a fashion, Moby's
>world. Mr. Fukuyama imagined a future defined by "economic calculation,
>the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns, and
>the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands." The appeal of Moby
>was that he would give us a way to enjoy this future; he would satisfy
>our "sophisticated consumer demands" through superior engineering.
>
>In 2002, having picked up a few million new fans, Moby got a chance to
>put this theory into practice with "18," and it was immediately clear
>that something had gone wrong. In the liner notes, he opined, "One
>problem in writing an essay for this record is that the circumstances of
>the world are in such a state of flux," and many of the songs were just
>as banal (and, somehow, as smug) as this bit of boilerplate.
>
>Too sophisticated to believe in musical genres, Moby caricatured them
>instead. "We Are All Made of Stars" had some vaguely new-wavey guitar, a
>gentle backbeat and lyrics that aped the spaced-out platitudes of a bad
>David Bowie song: "People they come together/People they fall
>apart/Nothing can stop us now/'Cause we are all made of stars." From the
>token hip-hop track ("Jam for the Ladies," which sounded a lot like the
>Chemical Brothers) to the "Play"-ish "Sunday (the Day Before My
>Birthday)" - which sounds less appealing, not more, when you learn that
>Moby was born on Sept. 11 - the album showed the limits of pop as science.
>
>Last year, Moby followed "18" with a stopgap techno album, "Baby Monkey"
>(credited to his alter ego, Voodoo Child), which was meant as a lark but
>sounded like an insult. He seemed to think he was a smart producer
>dabbling in a dumb genre he had long since outgrown (he called the album
>"very simple, melodic, electronic, dance music"), although the CD
>swiftly disproved the notion that techno was easy.
>
>And now comes "Hotel," packaged as a two-disc set: the album on one
>disc, and a series of "ambient" remixes on a second. Again, there are
>liner notes to guide us through the music. "I don't feel like making
>music that is airless and lifeless because I also really like people and
>the messy miasma of the human condition and I want to make messy, human
>records that are open and emotional," he writes, as if this truism
>unlocked a secret to music making.
>
>More than ever, the focus here is on Moby as a singer and songwriter,
>which is strange, because he is not very good at either job. In his
>effort to leave generic constraints behind, he has drifted toward some
>rather neutral variant of alternative-rock. In the lyrics, as in the
>liner notes, he seems to mistake obviousness for truth: the lead single
>is a mind-numbing song called, "Beautiful," where the romantic dialogue
>consists largely of couplets like, "I love you baby/I love you now/I
>love you baby/I love you now."
>
>This music isn't just dull, though. Like much of what Moby has produced
>since "Play," it's condescending, too. Much of it sounds like the work
>of a producer who thinks pop music is supposed to be kind of idiotic,
>and who thinks pop audiences should be glad that he deigns to give us
>what we want. Do we like sex? O.K., here's "I Like It," four singularly
>unpleasant minutes of heavy breathing. Do we like songs about how the
>world is happy and sad and good and bad? O.K., here's "Slipping Away,"
>with a wispy beat and Moby crooning, "Open to everything, happy and
>sad/Seeing the good when it's all going . . ." - you can finish the
>couplets yourself. And, knowing that we like familiarity, Moby has his
>collaborator, Laura Dawn, sing a slowed-down version of the New Order
>hit "Temptation."
>
>Maybe this isn't really Moby's fault so much as it is ours. Like so many
>other things in the late 1990's, his new paradigm seemed like a great
>idea: car commercials were going to be the new pop songs and laptop
>composers were going to be the new pop stars. But it turns out that we
>really do like those oversized personalities who clog the radio stations
>- some of whom even double as superior engineers.
>
>Mr. Fukuyama, in his famous obituary, might have written (but didn't
>quite, of course) that "boredom at the end of music will serve to get
>music started once again." That's an appealing idea, but it's also
>appealing to know, listening to "Hotel," that it won't be necessary. The
>end of music seems to have ended itself.
>
>
>
>--
>------------------------------------------------------------------------------
>tsheets@saturn5.com                                  <- You have found me
>http://www.ferrapsylix.com                           <- sub atomic 
>breakbeat
>"I just don't have the discipline to be a hippie"    <- Homer J. Simpson

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Moby gets skewered.

Jeez dude, it sure didn't take much provocation to get you to show your
hand again..

I sent you a retractory reply after you blew up at my statement to try
to defuse things a bit, knowing that my email had been a bit of a
pre-emptive strike, and a little nastily worded, at that.  I wanted to
keep the peace.

However, I did write my original message for the same reason- that
being that I've seen you go off on many tangents on this list, some of
them somewhat abusive, most wildly dismissive of any viewpoint but your
own, and some that look like just plain lefty-bait.

This crack about the NYT looked very much like the latter, given that
that newspaper is a popular target for right-wing pundits.  

In any case, at the end of the day, any discussion is better than none,
but let's cool the attacks on people you don't know- especially other
artists whose work you have no familiarity with.  Just because your
promotional style differs from others doesn't mean that SFR is not a
list where people are meant to share about their events.  

Have some heart, and some post-high school manners, bra.

Cheers,
-GC

At 03:47 PM 3/31/2005, Steve Osteen wrote:


>I just want to give a public apology to this list for the posts I made
>today.
>
>I'm extremely sensitive right now. Today is my 5th day being sober from
>a 2 year daily DXM addiction (about 1gram per day).

I can understand the lure of DXM (I intend to try a trip one of these days, 
once I find
a pure supplier... and have the time and no job and etc etc)  but how the 
hell does
one get addicted?  I can't imagine how the fogginess I get off of 
Robotussin et al
(for colds) being in any way alluring enough to go back and go back again.  the
disassociatives are a bit icky....  ok, K has quite the otherworldlyness 
and the
psychological escapism is obvious.... but DXM?  I didn't think it was that 
powerful

good luck,
doug

At 03:57 PM 3/31/2005, Douglas Fraser wrote:
>At 03:47 PM 3/31/2005, Steve Osteen wrote:
>>I just want to give a public apology to this list for the posts I made
>>today.
>>
>>I'm extremely sensitive right now. Today is my 5th day being sober from
>>a 2 year daily DXM addiction (about 1gram per day).
>
>I can understand the lure of DXM (I intend to try a trip one of these 
>days, once I find
>a pure supplier... and have the time and no job and etc etc)  but how the 
>hell does
>one get addicted?  I can't imagine how the fogginess I get off of 
>Robotussin et al
>(for colds) being in any way alluring enough to go back and go back 
>again.  the
>disassociatives are a bit icky....  ok, K has quite the otherworldlyness 
>and the
>psychological escapism is obvious.... but DXM?  I didn't think it was that 
>powerful

DXM is way stronger.  Imagine a wall, about 3 feet thick.  K puts you in 
middle of the wall, and DXM puts you on the other side.. but you can move 
around and be active.  I've had a lot of fun with it, but I can't bear the 
taste of cough syrup any more.  haven't "sipped the scissor" in a couple 
years..

sarilion

Thread-Topic: [sfraves]was public apology, now Everything begines with an E.
Thread-Index: AcU2TV6zc9IrBAtHTNWMysVjLmm51gAAuVtw
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "Douglas Fraser" <doug_fraser@microcinema.com>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 01 Apr 2005 00:58:00.0337 (UTC) FILETIME=[D9C14810:01C53655]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves]was public apology, now Everything begines with an E.


Thanks.

 feel like telling the story so I will:

I was always anti-drug until:

I attended a rave back in 98 and a friend gave me an E.
I loved it. It was a truly mind blowing experience. I connected with
everyone at the party. I remember dancing with a whole group of people,
making eye contact, the feeling of rubbing up against that stranger. The
way the music twisted open and became so full and beautiful. Colors were
vibrant. How strange I thought that we could feel so much and open
ourselves to complete strangers in such a way. I did more (though not a
lot, just an ocasional controlled thing).

Then:

I get a couple bad pills mixed with mdma/mda/dxm which gives me
seritonin syndrome and I get very sick. I research what happened to me
and discover DXM. Looking to experiement and for a safer trip (since dxm
is free of adulterants because it's legal) I order dexalone.

At first the trips were not that great. Compared to e, it was very
different. I continue to start to experiment more. Trying different
doses (the effects are completely different at different doses). I start
doing it weekly.

See, if ecstacy is going into yourself, DXM is the opposite. It is going
out  of yourself (which can be pretty damn euphoric)

So instead of being at a bright busy rave it's better enjoyed in the
dark with headphones on. Floating away. The euphoria of Out of your
body. Out of your problems. Talking with aliens. Talking to God. Visuals
that were better then any lazer show I had ever seen. The next thing I
knew, I was buying powder, packing pills, and doing it everyday. Two
years go by and I'm realizing that I'm killing myself and can't stop.
I'm mentally and physically addicted (some people dispute this, but it
is true, I'm a perfect example)

Yeah I manage to work a normal job, live a normal life and let no one
know that I'm tripping. Hiding it completely. But I'm so far away from
myself I'm nearly dead.

Although this post sounds very pro drug, please realize that dxm isn't
safe, it's an extremely powerfull drug and isn't for everyone, if you
are enzyme deficient it can be a terrible trip. If you choose to
experiement I suggest finding the dxm faq written by William White.

BTW powder is legal (and cheap at fifty cents for 500mg, A pretty deep
trips worth) and you really don't need to find a supplier. 100gram
bottles aren't hard to come by. Please don't be stupid like all the
people that kill themselves by not buying a $19 scale.

Steve
Http://www.tussinspace.com

Subject: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Question: How do you define community?

Spirit of Raving Question: How do you define Community?

IAHO: It's etymological. The origin of the word "community" comes from the 
Latin munus, which means the gift, and cum, which means together, among 
each other. So community literally means to give among each other.

Community can be defined as a group of people who welcome and honor 
gifts, and from those of whom give gifts to one another as well.

-- 
**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

Subject: Re: [sfraves]was Moby gets skewered. (Now public apology)

Heh....  I've actually accidently robo-tripped before.

I used to have the habit of detesting being sick so incredibly much 
that I'd naively assault my body with every cold remedy known to man in 
order to try to drown out the symptoms.  About the only thing I hated 
more than being sick was wasting a sick day on being sick.  This led to 
some rather extreme foolishness in cold-vanquishing cocktails.

My preferred mixture used to start with a dose/glass of alka-seltzer 
cold relief.  Then I'd toss in a dose of ny-quill and a dose of 
robotussin.... the CF kind with everything under the sun in it.  If I 
was feeling particularly bad, or was already addle-minded from being 
sick, I'd wind up using the ny-quill cup to measure the robo.... which 
comes out to something like four times the proper dose.  Take all that, 
add a feverishly sick condition, and allow that I hadn't eaten because 
being sick kills my appetite, and you get an intense, but unintentional 
DXM trip.... right before passing out for twelve hours.  In retrospect, 
that probably tore  my immune system to shreds, which would keep me 
sicker, longer.

On the plus side, it blew anything even remotely resembling phlegm or 
mucous right out of my system, brought down my fever, and BOY did I 
ever sleep soundly!

Oh, but did I mention how much I hated taking sick days?  Well, on days 
I had to work, I'd chase all of the above down with 4-8 shots of 
espresso and a couple of Red Bulls; so as to stay awake and at the 
computer.  In retrospect, this was probably even worse for my immune 
system; and I doubt that I was very productive in that state.

But who cared?  We were all owned tens of thousands of shares/options!  
If we all worked crazy hours, and didn't ever let anything stupid like 
a mere cold slow us down, we'd be rich come IPO time!  And then we'd 
all retire, by thirty, to some beach in Thailand!  Oh... wait...

Now that I'm older, and hopefully a little bit wiser, I barely use cold 
medicines at all.  And when I do, I usually eschew the "all-in-one" 
solutions, and try to take just barely enough of the one chemical I 
need to relieve the worst symptoms.  Though I do make an exception, 
still, for ny-quill if I have a hard-core "keep me up at night" kind of 
sick

So, so more robo-rolls, accidental or otherwise, for me.


cya,
john
